projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p:
Whereas our
Bi≈øhops, Deanes of our Cathedrall Churches, Archdeacons, Chapters and Colleges, & the other Cleargie of euery Dioce≈ø≈øe within the Prouince of Canterbury, being ≈øummoned & called by vertue of our Writ directed to the mo≈øt reuerend father in God IOHN late Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, and bearing date the 31. day of Ianuary in the first yeere of our Raigne of England, France and Ireland, and of Scotland the 37. to haue appeared before him in our Cathedrall Church of Saint Paul in London the 20. day of March then next en≈øuing, or el≈øewhere, as he ≈øhould haue thought it mo≈øt conuenient, to treat, con≈øent, and conclude vpon certaine difficult, and vrgent affaires mentioned in the ≈øaid Writte, Did thereupon at the time appointed, and
within the Cathedrall Church of Saint Paul afore≈øaid, a≈ø≈øemble them≈øelues and appeare in Conuocation for that purpo≈øe, according to our ≈øaid Writte before the Right reuerend Father in God Richard Bi≈øhop of London, duely (vpon a ≈øecond Writte of Ours dated the 9. day of March afore≈øaid) authorized, appointed and con≈øtituted, by rea≈øon of the ≈øaide Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury his death, Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid Conuocation, to execute tho≈øe things which by vertue of our fir≈øt Writ did appertaine to him the ≈øaid Archbi≈øhop to haue executed if he had liued: Wee for diuers vrgent and weighty cau≈øes and con≈øiderations vs thereunto e≈øpecially mouing, of our e≈øpecial grace, certaine knowledge, and meere motion, did by vertue of our Prerogatiue royal
and ≈øupreme Authoritie in cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øtical, giue and grant by our ≈øeuerall Letters Patents vnder our great Seale of England, the one dated the 12. day of April last past, and the other the 25. day of Iune then next following, full, free, and lawfull libertie, licence, power, and Authoritie vnto the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop of London Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid Conuocation, and to the other Bi≈øhops, Deanes, Archdeacons, Chapters and Colleges, and the rest of the Cleargie before mentioned of the ≈øaid Prouince, That they from time to time during our first Parliament now prorogued, might conferre, treate, debate, con≈øider, con≈øult, and agree of, and vpon ≈øuch Canons, Orders, Ordinances and Con≈øtitutions, as they ≈øhould thinke nece≈ø≈øary, fit, & conuenient for the honour
and ≈øeruice of Almighty God, the good and quiet of the Church, and the better gouernement thereof to be from time to time ob≈øerued, perfourmed, fulfilled and kept a≈øwel by the Archbi≈øhops of Canterbury, the Bi≈øhops & their Succe≈ø≈øours, and the re≈øt of the whole Clergie of the ≈øayd Prouince of Canterbury in their ≈øeveral Callings, Offices, Functions, Mini≈øteries, Degrees and admini≈øtrations, as al≈øo by all and euery Deane of the Arches, and other Iudge of the ≈øayd Archbi≈øhops Courts, Gardians of Spiritualties, Chancellors, Deanes and Chapters, Archdeacons, Commi≈ø≈øaries, Officials, Regi≈øters, and all and euery other Eccle≈øia≈øticall Officers, and their inferiour Mini≈øters what≈øoeuer of the ≈øame Prouince of Canterburie in their and euery of
their di≈øtinct Courts, and in the order and maner of their and euery of their proceedings: and by all other per≈øons mthin this Realme, as farre as lawfully being members of the Church, it may concerne them, as in our ≈øayd Letters Patents amongst other clau≈øes more at large doth appeare. Fora≈ømuch as the ≈øayd Bi≈øhop of London, Pre≈øident of the ≈øayd Conuocation, and others the ≈øayd Bi≈øhops, Deanes, Archdeacons, Chapters and Colledges, with the re≈øt of the Clergie hauing met together at the time and place before mentioned, and then and there by vertue of our ≈øaid authority granted vnto them, treated of, concluded, and agreed vpon certaine Canons, Orders, Ordinances and Con≈øtitutions, to the end and purpo≈øe by ∆≤s limited and pre≈øcribed vnto them,
and haue thereupon offred and pre≈øented the ≈øame vnto ∆≤s, mo≈øt humbly de≈øiring ∆≤s to giue our Royal a≈ø≈øent vnto their ≈øayd Canons, Orders, Ordinances, and Con≈øtitutions, according to the forme of a certaine Statute or Acte of Parliament made in that behalfe in the xxv. yeere of the Reigne of King Henry the eight, and by our ≈øayd Prerogatiue Royall, and ≈øupreme Authority in cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øticall, to ratifie by our Letters Patents vnder our great Seale of England, and to confirme the ≈øame: the title and tenour of them being word for word as en≈øueth:

div.head: Con≈øtitutions and Canons Eccle≈øia≈øticall treated vpon by the Bi≈øhop of London, Pre≈øident of the Conuocation for the Prouince of Canterbury, and the re≈øt of the Bi≈øhops and Cleargie of the ≈øaid Prouince: and agreed vpon with the Kings Maie≈øties licence in their Synode begun at London An.Dom.1603.
And in the yeere of the raigne of our Soueraigne Lord Iames by the grace of God, King of England, France, and Ireland the fir≈øt, and of Scotland the 37.
‚ùßOf the Church of England.
I. The Kings ≈øupremacie ouer the Church of England in cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øticall, to be maintained.
div.p:
AS our duety to the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maie≈øtie requireth, wee fir≈øt decree and ordaine, That the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury (from time to time) all Bi≈øhops of this prouince, all Deanes, Archdeacons, Par≈øons, Vicars, and all other
Eccle≈øia≈øticall per≈øons, ≈øhall faithfully keepe and ob≈øerue, and (as much as in them lieth) ≈øhall cau≈øe to bee ob≈øerued and kept of others, all and ≈øinguler Lawes and ≈øtatutes made for re≈øtoring to the Crowne of this kingdome, the ancient Iuri≈ødiction ouer the ≈øtate Eccle≈øia≈øtical, and aboli≈øhing of all forren power-repugnant to the ≈øame. Furthermore, al Eccle≈øia≈øtical per≈øons hauing cure of ≈øoules, and all other Preachers, and Readers of Diuinitie lectures, ≈øhall to the vttermo≈øt of their wit, knowledge, and learning, purely and ≈øincerely (without any colour or di≈øsimulation) teach, manife≈øt, open, and declare foure times euery yeere (at the lea≈øt) in their Sermons and other Collations and lectures, That all v≈øurped and forren power, (fora≈ømuch as the ≈øame hath no e≈øtabli≈øhment nor ground by the law of God) is for mo≈øt iu≈øt cau≈øes taken away and aboli≈øhed: and that therefore no maner of obedience, or ≈øubiection within his Maie≈øties Realmes and Dominions, is due vnto any ≈øuch forren power: but that the Kings power within his Realmes of England, Scotland and Ireland, and all other his Dominions and Countreys,
is the highe≈øt power vnder God, to whom all men, a≈øwell inhabitants, as borne within the ≈øame, do by Gods Lawes owe mo≈øt loyalty and obedience, afore and aboue all other Powers and Potentates in earth.

div.head: II. Impugners of the Kings ≈øupremacie cen≈øured.
div.p: WHo≈øoeuer ≈øhal hereafter affirme that the Kings Maie≈øty hath not the ≈øame authority in cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øtical that the godly Kings had among≈øt the Iewes, and Chri≈øtian Emperors in the Primitiue Church, or impeach in any part his Regall ≈øupremacie in the ≈øaid cau≈øes re≈øtored to the Crowne, and by the Lawes of this Realme therein e≈øtabli≈øhed, let him bee excommunicated ip≈øo facto, and not re≈øtored but only by the Archbi≈øhop after his repentance and publike reuocation of tho≈øe his wicked errours.

div.head: III. The Church of England a true and Apo≈øtolicall Church.
div.p:
WHo≈øoeuer ≈øhall hereafter affirme, that the Church of England by Lawe e≈øtabli≈øhed
vnder the Kings Maie≈øtie, is not a true and an Apo≈øtolical Church, teaching & maintaining the doctrine of the Apo≈øtles, let him be excommunicated ip≈øo facto, and not re≈øtored, but onely by the Archbi≈øhop after his repentance and publike reuocation of this his wicked errour.

div.head: IIII. Impugners of the publike wor≈øhip of God, e≈øtabli≈øhed in the Church of England cen≈øured.
div.p: WHo≈øoeuer ≈øhall herafter affirme that the forme of Gods wor≈øhip in the Church of England, e≈øtabli≈øhed by Law and conteined in the booke of Common Prayer, and admini≈øtration of Sacraments, is a corrupt, ≈øuper≈øtitious, or vnlawfull wor≈øhip of God, or containeth any thing in it that is repugnant to the Scriptures: let him be excommunicated ip≈øo facto, and not re≈øtored but by the Bi≈øhop of the place, or Archbi≈øhop, after his repentance and publike reuocation of ≈øuch his wicked errors.

div.head: V. Impugners of the Articles of Religion e≈øtabli≈øhed in the Church of England cen≈øured.
div.p: WHo≈øoeuer ≈øhall hereafter affirme that any of the nine and thirtie Articles agreed vpon by the Archbi≈øhops, and Bi≈øhops of both Prouinces, and the whole Cleargy in the Conuocation holden at LONDON, in the yeere of our Lorde God, one thou≈øand fiue hundred ≈øixty two, for the auoiding of diuer≈øities of opinions, and for the e≈øtabli≈øhing of con≈øent touching true Religion, are in any part ≈øuper≈øtitious or erroneous, or ≈øuch as hee may not with a good con≈øcience ≈øub≈øcribe vnto: let him bee excommunicated ip≈øo facto, and not re≈øtored, but onely by the Archbi≈øhop, after his repentance and publike reuocation of ≈øuch his wicked errors.

div.head: VI. Impugners of the Rites and Ceremonies e≈øtabli≈øhed in the Church of England cen≈øured.
div.p:
WHo≈øoeuer ≈øhal hereafter affirme, that the Rites and Ceremonies of the Church of England by Law e≈øtabli≈øhed, are wicked, Antichri≈øtian, or ≈øuper≈øtitious,
or ≈øuch as beeing commanded by lawfull authoritie, men who are zealou≈øly and godly affected, may not with any good con≈øcience approue them, v≈øe them, or as occa≈øion requireth ≈øub≈øcribe vnto them: let him bee excommunicated ip≈øo facto, and not re≈øtored, vntill he repent and publikely reuoke ≈øuch his wicked errours.

div.head: VII. Impugners of the gouernment of the Church of England by Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, &c. cen≈øured.
div.p: WHo≈øoeuer ≈øhal hereafter affirme, that the gouernement of the Church of England, vnder his Maie≈øty by Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, Deanes, Archdeacons, and the re≈øt that beare office in the ≈øame, is Antichri≈øtian or repugnant to the word of God: let him be excommunicated ip≈øo facto, and ≈øo continue vntill he repent and publikely reuoke ≈øuch his wicked errors.

div.head:
VIII. Impugners of the forme of con≈øecrating and ordering
Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, &c. in the Church of England cen≈øured.
div.p: WHo≈øoeuer ≈øhall hereafter affirme or teach, that the fourme and maner of making and con≈øecrating Bi≈øhops, Prie≈øts, or Deacons, conteineth any thing in it, that is repugnant to the word of God, or that they who are made Bi≈øhops, Prie≈øtes, or Deacons in that forme are not lawfully made, nor ought to be accounted either by them≈øelues or by others, to be truly either Bi≈øhops, Prie≈øts, or Deacons, vntil they haue ≈øome other calling to tho≈øe diuine Offices: let him bee excommunicated ip≈øo facto, not to bee re≈øtored vntill he repent and publikely reuoke ≈øuch his wicked errours.

div.head: IX. Authours of Schi≈øme in the Church of England cen≈øured.
div.p:
WHo≈øoeuer ≈øhall hereafter ≈øeparate them≈øelues from the Communion of Saints as it is approoued by the Apo≈øtles rules, in the Church of England, & combine them≈øelues together in a new brotherhood, accounting the Chri≈øtians who are conformable
to the Doctrine, Gouernment, Rites, and Ceremonies of the Church of England, to be prophane and vnmeete for them to ioyne with in Chri≈øtian profe≈øsion: let them bee excommunicated ip≈øo facto, and not re≈øtored, but by the Archbi≈øhop, after their repentance and publike reuocation of ≈øuch their wicked errors.

div.head: X. Maintainers of Schi≈ømatickes in the Church of England cen≈øured.
div.p:
WHo≈øoeuer ≈øhall heerafter affirme, That ≈øuch Mini≈øters as refu≈øe to ≈øub≈øcribe to the forme and maner of Gods wor≈øhip in the Church of England pre≈øcribed in the Communion Booke, and their adherents, may truly take vnto them the name of another Church not e≈øtabli≈øhed by Lawe, and dare pre≈øume to publi≈øh it, that this their pretended Church hath of long time groaned vnder the burden of certaine grieuances impo≈øed vpon it, and vpon the members thereof before mentioned by the Church of England, and the Orders and Con≈øtitutions therein by Law e≈øtabli≈øhed: Let them be excommunicated,
and not re≈øtored vntill they repent and publikely reuoke ≈øuch their wicked errors.

div.head: XI. Maintainers of Conuenticles cen≈øured.
div.p: WHo≈øoeuer ≈øhall hereafter affirme or maintaine, That there are within this Realme other meetings, a≈ø≈øemblies or congregations of the Kings borne Subiects, then ≈øuch as by the lawes of this land are held and allowed, which may rightly challenge to them≈øelues the name of true and lawful Churches: let him be excommunicated and not re≈øtored but by the Archbi≈øhop, after his repentance and publike reuocation of ≈øuch his wicked errors.

div.head: XII. Maintainers of Con≈øtitutions made in Conuenticles, cen≈øured.
div.p:
WHo≈øoeuer ≈øhal hereafter affirme that it is lawfull for any ≈øort of Mini≈øters and Lay per≈øons, or either of them to ioyne together, and make Rules, Orders, or Con≈øtitutions in cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øticall without the Kings authoritie, and ≈øhall ≈øubmit them≈øelues to be ruled and gouerned by them: let
them be excommunicated ip≈øo facto, and not be re≈øtored vntill they repent, and publikely reuoke tho≈øe their wicked and Anabapti≈øticall errors.

div.head: Of diuine Seruice, and admini≈øtration of the Sacraments.
XIII. Due celebration of Sundayes and Holy dayes.
div.p:
ALl maner of per≈øons within the Church of England ≈øhall from henceforth celebrate and keepe the Lords day, commonly called Sunday, and other Holy dayes according to Gods holy will and plea≈øure, and the Orders of the Church of England pre≈øcribed in that behalfe: that is, in hearing the word of God read and taught, in priuate and publike prayers: in acknowledging their offences to God, and amendement of the ≈øame, in reconciling them≈øelues charitably to their neighbours where di≈øplea≈øure hath bene, in oftentimes receiuing the Communion of the body & blood
of Chri≈øt, in vi≈øiting of the poore and ≈øicke, v≈øing all godly and ≈øober conuer≈øation.

div.head: XIIII. The pre≈øcript forme of Diuine Seruice to bee v≈øed on Sundayes and Holy dayes.
div.p: THe Common prayer ≈øhalbe ≈øaid or ≈øung di≈øtinctly and reuerently vpon ≈øuch daies as are appointed to be kept holy by the Booke of Common prayer, and their Eeues, and at conuenient and v≈øuall times of tho≈øe daies, and in ≈øuch place of euery Church as the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, or Eccle≈øia≈øticall Ordinary of the place ≈øhall thinke meete for the largene≈ø≈øe or ≈øtraitne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øame, ≈øo as the people may bee mo≈øt edified. All Mini≈øters likewi≈øe ≈øhall ob≈øerue the Orders, Rites, and Ceremonies pre≈øcribed in the Booke of Common prayer, a≈øwell in reading the holy Scriptures and ≈øaying of prayers, as in admini≈øtration of the Sacraments, without either dimini≈øhing in regard of preaching, or in any other re≈øpect, or adding any thing in the matter or forme thereof.

div.head: XV. The Letanie to bee read on Wedne≈ødayes and Fridayes.
div.p: THe Letany ≈øhalbe ≈øaid or ≈øung when, and as it is ≈øet downe in the Booke of Common prayer, by the Par≈øons, Vicars, Mini≈øters, or Curats in all Cathedrall, Collegiat, Pari≈øh Churches and Chappels, in ≈øome conuenient place, according to the di≈øcretion of the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, or Eccle≈øia≈øticall Ordinarie of the place. And that wee may ≈øpeake more particularly, vpon Wedne≈ødayes and Fridayes weekely, though they bee not Holy dayes, the Mini≈øter at the accu≈øtomed houres of Seruice, ≈øhall re≈øort to the Church and Chappel, and warning being giuen to the people by tolling of a Bell, ≈øhall ≈øay the Letanie pre≈øcribed in the Booke of Common prayer: whereunto wee wi≈øh euery Hou≈øholder dwelling within halfe a mile of the Church, to come or ≈øend one at the lea≈øt of his Hou≈øhold fit to ioyne with the Mini≈øter in prayers.

div.head: XVI. Colledges to v≈øe the pre≈øcript forme of Diuine Seruice.
div.p: IN the whole Diuine Seruice, and Admini≈øtration of the holy Communion, in all Colledges and Halles in both Vniuer≈øities, the Order, Forme, and Ceremonies ≈øhall be duely ob≈øerued as they are ≈øet downe and pre≈øcribed in the booke of Common prayer, without any omi≈øsion or alteration.

div.head: XVII. Students in Colledges to weare Surpli≈øses, in time of Diuine Seruice.
div.p: ALl Ma≈øters and Fellowes of Colledges or Halles, and al the Schollers and Students in either of the Vniuer≈øities, ≈øhall in their Churches and Chappels vpon all Sundayes, Holy dayes, and their Eues, at the time of Diuine Seruice weare Surpli≈ø≈øes, according to the order of the Church of England: and ≈øuch as are Graduats ≈øhall agreeably were with their Surpli≈ø≈øes, ≈øuch Hoods as doe ≈øeuerally appertaine to their Degrees.

div.head: XVIII. A reuerence and attention to bee v≈øed within the Church in time of Diuine Seruice.
div.p:
IN the time of Diuine Seruice, and of euery part thereof, all due reuerence is to be v≈øed: For it is according to the Apo≈øtles Rule: Let all things bee done decently, and according to Order. An≈øwerable to which Decencie and Order, We iudge the≈øe our directions following: No man ≈øhall couer his head in the Church or Chappel in the time of Diuine Seruice, except he haue ≈øome infirmitie. In which ca≈øe let him weare a Nightcap or Coife. All maner of per≈øons then pre≈øent ≈øhall reuerently kneele vpon their knees when the Generall Confe≈øsion, Letanie, and other Prayers are read, and ≈øhall ≈øtand vp at the ≈øaying of the Beleefe, according to the Rules in that behalfe pre≈øcribed in the Booke of Common Prayer. And likewi≈øe when in time of Diuine Seruice the Lord IESVS ≈øhalbe mentioned, due and lowly reuerence ≈øhall bee done by all per≈øons pre≈øent as it hath bene accu≈øtomed: te≈øtifying by the≈øe outward Ceremonies and ge≈øtures, their inward humilitie, Chri≈øtian re≈øolution,
and due acknowledgement that the Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, the true and eternal Sonne of God, is the onely Sauiour of the world, in whom alone all the Mercies, Graces, and Promi≈øes of God to mankinde for this life and the life to come are fully and wholly compri≈øed. None, either man, woman, or childe, of what calling ≈øoeuer, ≈øhall be otherwi≈øe at ≈øuch times bu≈øied in the Church, then in quiet attendance to heare, marke, and vnder≈øtand that which is read, preached, or mini≈øtred; Saying in their due places audibly with the Mini≈øter, the Confe≈øsion, the Lords Prayer, and the Creed, and making ≈øuch other an≈øweres to the publique Prayers as are appointed in the Booke of Common prayer: neither ≈øhall they di≈øturbe the Seruice or Sermon by walking or Talking, or any other way, nor depart out of the Church during the time of Seruice, and Sermon, without ≈øome vrgent or rea≈øonable cau≈øe.

div.head: XIX. Loyterers not to bee ≈øuffered neere the Church in time of Diuine Seruice.
div.p:
THe Churchwardens or Que≈øtmen, and their a≈øsi≈øtants, ≈øhall not ≈øuffer any idle
per≈øons to abide either in the Churchyard or Church porch, during the time of Diuine Seruice or preaching: but ≈øhall cau≈øe them either to come in, or to depart.

div.head: XX. Bread and Wine to be prouided again≈øt euery Communion.
div.p: THe Churchwardens of euery Pari≈øh again≈øt the time of euery Communion, ≈øhal at the charge of the Pari≈øh, with the aduice and direction of the Mini≈øter, prouide a ≈øufficient quantitie of fine white Bread, and of good and whole≈øome Wine for the number of Communicants that ≈øhall from time to time receiue there: which Wine we require to bee brought to the Communion Table in a cleane and ≈øweete ≈øtanding Pot, or Stoope of Pewter, if not of purer mettall.

div.head: XXI. The Communion to be thrice a yeere receiued.
div.p:
IN euery Pari≈øh Church and Chappel where Sacraments are to bee admini≈øtred within this Realme, the holy Communion ≈øhall bee mini≈øtred by the Par≈øon, Vicar, or Mini≈øter, ≈øo often, and at ≈øuch times as euery Pari≈øhioner
may Communicate at the lea≈øt thri≈øe in the yeere (whereof the Fea≈øt of Ea≈øter to bee one) according as they are appointed by the booke of Common Prayer. Prouided, that euery Mini≈øter as oft as hee admini≈øtreth the Communion, ≈øhall fir≈øt receiue the Sacrament him≈øelfe. Furthermore no Bread or Wine newly brought ≈øhalbe v≈øed: but fir≈øt the words of In≈øtitution ≈øhalbe rehear≈øed when the ≈øaid Bread and Wine bee pre≈øent vpon the Communion Table. Likewi≈øe the Mini≈øter ≈øhal deliuer both the Bread and the Wine to euery Communicant ≈øeuerally.

div.head: XXII. Warning to be giuen beforehand for the Communion.
div.p:
WHereas euery Lay per≈øon is bound to receiue the holy Communion thrice euery yeere, and many notwith≈øtanding doe not receiue that Sacrament once in a yeere: We doe require euery Mini≈øter to giue warning to his Pari≈øhioners publikely in the Church at Morning prayer the Sunday before euery time of his admini≈øtring
that holy Sacrament, for their better preparation of them≈øelues: Which ≈øaid warning, We enioyne the ≈øayd Pari≈øhioners to accept and obey vnder the penaltie and danger of the Law.

div.head: XXIII. Students in Colledges to receiue the Communion foure times a yeere.
div.p:
IN all Colledges and Halles within both the Vniuer≈øities, the Ma≈øters and Fellowes, ≈øuch e≈øpecially as haue any Pupils, ≈øhall be carefull that all their ≈øaid Pupils, and the re≈øt that remaine among≈øt them be wel brought vp and throughly in≈øtructed in poynts of Religion, & that they doe diligently frequent publike Seruice and Sermons, and receiue the holy Communion: which we ordaine to be admini≈øtred in all ≈øuch Colledges and Halles the fir≈øt or ≈øecond Sunday of euery Moneth, Requiring all the ≈øayd Ma≈øters, Fellowes, and Schollers, and all the re≈øt of the Students, Officers and all other the ≈øeruants there ≈øo to be ordered, that euery one of them ≈øhall Communicate foure times in the yeere at the lea≈øt, kneeling reuerently and decently vpon their knees according
to the order of the Communion Booke pre≈øcribed in that behalfe.

div.head: XXIIII. Copes to be worne in Cathedral Churches by tho≈øe that admini≈øter the Communion.
div.p: IN all Cathedrall and Collegiat Churches, the holy Communion ≈øhall bee admini≈øtred vpon principall Fea≈øt-dayes, ≈øometimes by the Bi≈øhop if he be pre≈øent, and ≈øometimes by the Deane: and at ≈øome times by a Canon or Prebendarie, the principall Mini≈øter v≈øing a decent Coape, and being a≈øsi≈øted with the Go≈øpeller and Epi≈øtler agreeably according to the Aduerti≈øements publi≈øhed Anno 7. Elizabethae: the ≈øaid Communion to bee admini≈øtred at ≈øuch times and with ≈øuch limitation, as is ≈øpecified in the Booke of Common prayer. Prouided, that no ≈øuch limitation by any con≈øtruction ≈øhall bee allowed of, but that all Deanes, Wardens, Ma≈øters, or Heads of Cathedrall and Collegiate Churches, Prebendaries, Canons, Vicars, Petticannons, Singingmen, and all others of the Foundation, ≈øhall receiue the Communion foure times yeerely at the lea≈øt.

div.head: XXV. Surpli≈øses and Hoods to bee worne in Cathedrall Churches when there is no Communion.
div.p: IN the time of Diuine Seruice and Prayers in all Cathedrall and Collegiat Churches, when there is no Communion, it ≈øhall bee ≈øufficient to weare Surpli≈ø≈øes: ≈øauing that all Deanes, Ma≈øters and Heads of Collegiat Churches, Canons and Prebendaries being Graduats, ≈øhal daily at the times both of Prayer and Preaching, weare with their Surpli≈ø≈øes, ≈øuch Hoods as are agreeable to their degrees.

div.head: XXVI. Notorious offendours not to bee admitted to the Communion.
div.p:
NO Mini≈øter ≈øhal in any wi≈øe admit to the receiuing of the holy Communion, any of his Cure or Flocke which bee openly knowen to liue in ≈øinne notorious without repentance, Nor any who haue maliciou≈øly and openly contended with their neighbours, vntill they ≈øhall be reconciled: Nor any Churchwardens or Sidemen, who hauing taken their oathes to pre≈øent to their Ordinaries all ≈øuch publike offences as they are particularly charged
to inquire of in their ≈øeuerall Pari≈øhes ≈øhall (notwith≈øtanding their ≈øaid oathes, and that their faithfull di≈øcharging of them, is the chiefe meanes whereby publike ≈øinnes and offences may be reformed and puni≈øhed) wittingly and willingly, de≈øperately and irreligiou≈øly incurre the horrible crime of Periurie, either in neglecting or in refu≈øing to pre≈øent ≈øuch of the ≈øayd enormities and publike offences, as they know them≈øelues to be committed in their ≈øayd Pari≈øhes, or are notoriou≈øly offen≈øiue to the Congregation there: although they bee vrged by ≈øome of their neighbours, or by their Mini≈øter, or by their Ordinary him≈øelfe, to di≈øcharge their con≈øciences by pre≈øenting of them, and not to incurre ≈øo de≈øperately the ≈øaid horrible ≈øinne of Periurie.

div.head: XXVII. Schi≈ømaticks not to be admitted to the CoÃÑmunion.
div.p:
NO Mini≈øter when hee celebrateth the Communion, ≈øhall wittingly admini≈øter the ≈øame to any, but to ≈øuch as kneele, vnder paine of ≈øu≈øpen≈øion, nor vnder the like paine to any that refu≈øe to bee pre≈øent at publike Prayers, according to the Orders of the
Church of England, nor to any that are common and notorious deprauers of the Booke of Common Prayer, and admini≈øtration of the Sacraments, and of the Orders, Rites, and Ceremonies therein pre≈øcribed, or of any thing that is conteined in any of the Articles agreed vpon in the Conuocation 1562. or of any thing conteined in the Book of ordering Prie≈øts and Bi≈øhops, or to any that haue ≈øpoken again≈øt and depraued his Maie≈øties ≈øoueraigne Authoritie in cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øticall: Except euery ≈øuch per≈øon ≈øhall fir≈øt acknowledge to the Mini≈øter before the Churchwardens, his repentance for the ≈øame, and promi≈øe by word (if he cannot write) that hee will doe ≈øo no more: and except (if he can write) he ≈øhall fir≈øt do the ≈øame vnder his hand-writing, to bee deliuered to the Mini≈øter, and by him ≈øent to the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, or Ordinarie of the place. Prouided that euery Mini≈øter ≈øo repelling any (as is ≈øpecified either in this or in the next precedent Con≈øtitution) ≈øhall vpon complaint, or being required by the Ordinarie, ≈øignifie the cau≈øe thereof vnto him, and therein obey his Order and direction.

div.head: XXVIII. Strangers not to be admitted to the Communion.
div.p: THe Churchwardens or Que≈øtmen, and their A≈øsi≈øtants, ≈øhall marke a≈øwell as the Mini≈øter, whether all and euery of the Pari≈øhioners, come ≈øo often euery yeere to the holy Communion as the Lawes and our Con≈øtitutions do require: And whether any Strangers come often and commonly from other Pari≈øhes to their Church, and ≈øhall ≈øhew their Mini≈øter of them, le≈øt perhaps they be admitted to the Lords Table among≈øt others: which they ≈øhall forbid, and remit ≈øuch home to their owne pari≈øh Churches and Mini≈øters, there to receiue the Communion with the re≈øt of their owne neighbours.

div.head: XXIX. Fathers not to be Godfathers in Bapti≈øme, nor children not Communicants.
div.p:
NO Parent ≈øhall bee vrged to bee pre≈øent, nor bee admitted to an≈øwere as Godfather for his owne child: nor any Godfather or Godmother ≈øhalbe ≈øuffred to make any other an≈øwere or ≈øpeech, then by the Booke of Common prayer is pre≈øcribed in that behalfe.
Neither ≈øhall any per≈øon be admitted Godfather or Godmother to any child at Chri≈øtning or Confirmation, before the ≈øaid per≈øon ≈øo vndertaking hath receiued the holy CoÃÑmunion.

div.head: XXX. The lawfull v≈øe of the Cro≈øse in Bapti≈øme explaned.
div.p: WEe are ≈øorie that his Maie≈øties mo≈øt princely care and paines taken in the Conference at Hampton Court, among≈øt many other points, touching this one of the Cro≈ø≈øe in Bapti≈øme, hath taken no better effect with many, but that ≈øtill the v≈øe of it in Bapti≈øme is ≈øo greatly ≈øtuck at and impugned. For the further declaration therfore of the true v≈øe of this Ceremonie, and for the remouing of all ≈øuch ≈øcruple as might any wayes trouble the con≈øciences of them who are indeed rightly religious, following the royall ≈øteps of our mo≈øt worthy King, becau≈øe he therein followeth the rules of the Scriptures, and the practi≈øe of the Primitiue Church: we do commend to al the true members of the Church of England the≈øe our directions & ob≈øeruations en≈øuing.

Fir≈øt, it is to be ob≈øerued, that although the
Iewes & Ethnicks derided both the Apo≈øtles, and the re≈øt of the Chri≈øtians for preaching and beleeuing in him who was crucified vpon the Cro≈ø≈øe: yet all both Apo≈øtles and Chri≈øtians were ≈øo farre from beeing di≈øcouraged from their profe≈øsion by the ignominie of the Cro≈ø≈øe, as they rather reioyced and triumphed in it. Yea, the holy Gho≈øt by the mouthes of the Apo≈øtles did honour the Name of the Cro≈ø≈øe (being hatefull among the Iewes) ≈øo farre, that vnder it, he comprehended not onely Chri≈øt crucified, but the force, effects, and merits of his Death and Pa≈øsion, with all the comforts, fruits, and promi≈øes which wee receiue or expect thereby.

Secondlly, the honour and dignitie of the Name of the Cro≈ø≈øe, begat a reuerend e≈øtimation euen in the Apo≈øtles times (for ought that is knowen to the contrary) of the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe: which the Chri≈øtians ≈øhortly after v≈øed in all their actions, thereby making an outward ≈øhew & profe≈øsion euen to the a≈øtoni≈øhment of the Iewes, that they were not a≈øhamed to acknowledge him for their Lord and Sauiour, who died for them vpon the Cro≈ø≈øe.
And this ≈øigne they did not onely v≈øe them≈øelues with a kinde of glory, when they met with any Iewes, but ≈øigned therewith their children when they were Chri≈øtned, to dedicate them by that badge to his ≈øeruice, who≈øe benefits be≈øtowed vpon them in Bapti≈øme, the name of the Cro≈ø≈øe did repre≈øent. And this v≈øe of the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe in Bapti≈øme was held in the Primitiue Church, as well by the Greekes as the Latines, with one con≈øent and great applau≈øe. At what time, if any had oppo≈øed them≈øelues again≈øt it, they would certainely haue beene cen≈øured as enemies of the name of the Cro≈ø≈øe, & con≈øequently of Chri≈øts merits, the ≈øigne whereof they could no better endure. This continuall and generall v≈øe of the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe, is euident by many te≈øtimonies of the ancient Fathers.

Thirdly, it mu≈øt be confe≈ø≈øed that in proce≈ø≈øe of time, the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe was greatly abu≈øed in the Church of Rome, e≈øpecially after that corruption of Popery had once po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed it But the abu≈øe of a thing doth not take away the lawfull v≈øe of it. Nay, ≈øo farre was it from the purpo≈øe of the Church of England, to for≈øake
and reiect the Churches of Italie, France, Spaine, Germany, or any ≈øuch like Churches in all things which they helde and practi≈øed, that, as the Apologie of the Church of England confe≈ø≈øeth, it doth with reuerence retaine tho≈øe Ceremonies which doe neither endammage the Church of God, nor offende the minds of ≈øober men: and onely departed from them in tho≈øe particular points, wherein they were fallen both from them≈øelues in their ancient integritie, & from the Apo≈øtolicall Churches which were their fir≈øt founders. In which re≈øpect, among≈øt ≈øome other very ancient Ceremonies, the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe in Bapti≈øme hath bene retained in this Church both by the iudgement and practi≈øe of tho≈øe reuerend Fathers and great Diuines in the dayes of King Edward the ≈øixth, of whom ≈øome con≈øtantly ≈øuffered for the profe≈øsion of the trueth: and others being exiled in the time of Queene Mary, did after their returne in the beginning of the Reigne of our late dread Soueraigne, continually defend and v≈øe the ≈øame. This re≈øolution and practi≈øe of our Church hath beene allowed and approoued by the cen≈øure vpon
the Communion Booke in King Edward the ≈øixt his dayes, and by the harmonie of confe≈ø≈øions of latter yeeres: becau≈øe in deede the v≈øe of this ≈øigne in Bapti≈øme was euer accompanied here with ≈øuch ≈øufficient cautions and exceptions again≈øt all Popi≈øh Super≈øtition and errour, as in the like ca≈øes are either fit or conuenient.

Fir≈øt, the Church of England ≈øince the aboli≈øhing of Poperie hath euer held and taught, and ≈øo doth hold and teach ≈øtill, that the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe v≈øed in Bapti≈øme, is no part of the ≈øub≈øtance of that Sacrament. For when the Mini≈øter dipping the Infant in Water, or laying Water vpon the face of it (as the maner al≈øo is) hath pronounced the≈øe wordes, I baptize thee in the Name of the Father, and of the Sonne, and of the holy Ghost, the Infant is fully and perfectly baptized. So as the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe being afterwards v≈øed, doeth neither adde any thing to the vertue or perfection of Bapti≈øme, nor being omitted doeth detract any thing from the effect and ≈øub≈øtance of it.

Secondly, it is apparant in the Communion Booke, that the Infant baptized is by vertue of
Bapti≈øme, before it be ≈øigned with the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe, receiued into the Congregation of Chri≈øts flocke as a perfect member thereof, and not by any power a≈øcribed vnto the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe So that for the very remembrance of the Cro≈ø≈øe, which is very precious to all them that rightly beleeue in Ie≈øu Chri≈øt, and in the other re≈øpects mentioned, the Church of England hath reteined ≈øtill the ≈øigne of it in Bapti≈øme: following therein the Primitiue and Apo≈øtolicall Churches, & accounting it a lawful outward Ceremony & honourable Badge, whereby the Infant is dedicated to the ≈øeruice of him that died vpon the Cro≈ø≈øe, as by the words v≈øed in the Booke of Common prayer it may appeare.

La≈øtly, the v≈øe of the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe in Bapti≈øme, beeing thus purged from all Popi≈øh ≈øuper≈øtition and errour, and reduced in the Church of England to the primary In≈øtitution of it vpon tho≈øe true rules of Doctrine concerning things indifferent, which are con≈øonant to the word of God, and the iudgements of all the ancient Fathers: Wee hold it the part of euery priuate man, both Mini≈øter and other,
reuerently to reteine the true v≈øe of it pre≈øcribed by publike Authoritie, con≈øidering that things of them≈øelues indifferent, doe in ≈øome ≈øort alter their natures, when they are either commanded or forbidden by a lawfull Magi≈øtrate: and may not be omitted at euery mans plea≈øure contrary to the Law, when they bee coÃÑmanded, nor v≈øed when they are prohibited.

div.head: ¬∂ Mini≈øters their Ordination, function, and charge.
XXXI. Foure ≈øolemne times appointed for the making of Mini≈øters.
div.p:
FOra≈ømuch as the ancient Fathers of the Church led by example of the Apo≈øtles, appointed Prayers and Fa≈øts to bee v≈øed at the ≈øolemne ordering of Mini≈øters, & to that purpo≈øe allotted certaine times, in which onely ≈øacred Orders might be giuen or conferred: We following their holy and Religious example, doe con≈øtitute & decree, That no Deacons or Mini≈øters be made and ordained, but onely vpon
the Sundayes immediatly following Ieiunia quatuor temporum, commonly called Ember weekes, appointed in ancient time for Prayer and Fa≈øting (purpo≈øely for this cau≈øe at their fir≈øt In≈øtitution) and ≈øo continued at this day in the Church of England: and that this bee done in the Cathedrall or Pari≈øh Church where the Bi≈øhop re≈øideth, and in the time of diuine Seruice, in the pre≈øence not onely of the Archdeacon, but of the Deane and two Prebendaries at the lea≈øt, or (if they ≈øhall happen by any lawful cau≈øe to be let or hindered) in the pre≈øence of foure other graue per≈øons being ma≈øters of Arts at the lea≈øt, and allowed for publike Preachers.

div.head: XXXII. None to bee made Deacon and Mini≈øter, both in one day.
div.p:
THe Office of a Deacon being a ≈øtep or degree to the Mini≈øtery according to the iudgment of the ancient Fathers, and the practi≈øe of the Primitiue Church: We doe ordaine and appoint, that hereafter no Bi≈øhop ≈øhall make any per≈øon of what qualities or gifts ≈øoeuer, a Deacon and a Mini≈øter, both together
vpon one day: but that the order in that behalfe pre≈øcribed in the Booke of making and con≈øecrating Bi≈øhops, Prie≈øtes, and Deacons be ≈øtrictly ob≈øerued. Not that alwayes euery Deacon ≈øhould be kept from the Mini≈øterie for a whole yeere when the Bi≈øhop ≈øhall find good cau≈øe to the contrary: but that there being now foure times appointed in euery yeere for the ordination of Deacons and Mini≈øters, there may euer be ≈øome time of trial of their behauiour in the office of Deacon, before they bee admitted to the Order of Prie≈øthood.

div.head: XXXIII. The Titles of ≈øuch as are to be made Mini≈øters.
div.p:
IT hath beene long ≈øince prouided by many decrees of the ancient Fathers, that none ≈øhould be admitted either Deacon or Prie≈øt, who had not fir≈øt ≈øome certain place where he might v≈øe his Function. According to which examples we doe ordaine, that henceforth no per≈øon ≈øhall be admitted into ≈øacred Orders, except he ≈øhall at that time exhibite to the Bi≈øhop of whome hee de≈øireth Impo≈øition of hands, a pre≈øentation of him≈øelfe to ≈øome Eccle≈øia≈øticall
preferment then voyd in that Dioce≈ø≈øe: or ≈øhal bring to the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop a true & vndoubted Certificate, that either he is prouided of ≈øome Church within the ≈øaid Dioce≈ø≈øe, where he may attend the Cure of ≈øoules, or of ≈øome Mini≈øters place vacant, either in the Cathedral Church of that Dioce≈ø≈øe, or in ≈øome other Collegiat Church therein al≈øo ≈øcituate, where he may execute his Mini≈øterie: or that he is a Fellow, or in right as a Fellow, or to bee a Conduct or Chapleine in ≈øome Colledge in Cambridge or Oxford: or except he be a Ma≈øter of Arts of fiue yeeres ≈øtanding, that liueth of his owne charge in either of the Vniuer≈øities: or except by the Bi≈øhop him≈øelfe, that doth ordaine him Mini≈øter, he be ≈øhortly after to be admitted either to ≈øome Benefice or Curate≈øhip then voyd. And if any Bi≈øhop ≈øhall admit any per≈øon into the Mini≈øtery that hath none of the≈øe Titles as is afore≈øaid, then he ≈øhal keepe and maintaine him with all things nece≈ø≈øary, till he doe preferre him to ≈øome Eccle≈øia≈øtical liuing. And if the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop ≈øhall refu≈øe ≈øo to doe, hee ≈øhall bee ≈øu≈øpended by the Archbi≈øhop being a≈øsi≈øted with another Bi≈øhop,
from giuing of Orders by the ≈øpace of a yeere.

div.head: XXXIIII. The qualitie of ≈øuch as are to bee made Ministers.
div.p:
NO Bi≈øhop ≈øhall hencefoorth admit any per≈øon into ≈øacred Orders which is not of his owne Dioce≈ø≈øe, except he be either of one of the Vniuer≈øities of this Realme, or except hee ≈øhall bring letters Dimi≈ø≈øory (≈øo tearmed) from the Bi≈øhop of who≈øe Dioce≈ø≈øe he is, and de≈øiring to be a Deacon, is three and twentie yeeres olde, and to bee a Prie≈øt foure and twenty yeeres complete, and hath taken ≈øome degree of Schoole in either of the ≈øaide Vniuer≈øities, or at the lea≈øt, except hee be able to yeeld an accompt of his Faith in Latine, according to the Articles of Religion approoued in the Synode of the Bi≈øhops and Cleargie of this Realme 1562, and to confirme the ≈øame by ≈øufficient te≈øtimonies out of the holy Scriptures; and except moreouer, he ≈øhall then exhibite letters Te≈øtimoniall of his good life and conuer≈øation vnder the Seale of ≈øome College in Cambridge or Oxford, where before he remained,
or of three or foure graue Mini≈øters, together with the ≈øub≈øcription and te≈øtimonie of other credible per≈øons, who haue knowen his life and behauiour by the ≈øpace of three yeeres next before.

div.head: XXXV. The examination of ≈øuch as are to bee made Ministers.
div.p:
THe Bi≈øhop before hee admit any per≈øon to holy Orders, ≈øhall diligently examine him in the pre≈øence of tho≈øe Mini≈øters that ≈øhal a≈øsi≈øt him at the Impo≈øition of hands. And if the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop haue any lawfull impediment, he ≈øhall cau≈øe the ≈øaid Mini≈øters carefully to examine euery ≈øuch per≈øon ≈øo to bee ordered. Prouided that they who ≈øhall a≈øsi≈øt the Bi≈øhop in examining and laying on of handes, ≈øhall bee of his Cathedrall Church if they may conueniently bee had, or other ≈øufficient Preachers of the ≈øame Dioce≈ø≈øe, to the number of three at the lea≈øt. And if any bi≈øhop or Suffragan ≈øhal admit any to ≈øacred Orders who is not ≈øo qualified & examined, as before we haue ordeined: the Archbi≈øhop of this prouince hauing notice thereof, & being a≈øsi≈øted
therein by one Bi≈øhop, ≈øhall ≈øu≈øpend the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop or Suffragan ≈øo offending, from making either Deacons or Prie≈øts for the ≈øpace of two yeeres.

div.head: XXXVI. Sub≈øcription required of ≈øuch as are to bee made Ministers.
div.p: NO per≈øon ≈øhall hereafter be receiued into the Mini≈øtery, nor either by In≈øtitution or Collation admitted to any Eccle≈øia≈øtical liuing, nor ≈øuffered to Preach, to Catechize, or to be a Lecturer, or Reader of Diuinitie in either Vniuer≈øity, or in any Cathedrall or Collegiat Church, City or market Towne, pari≈øh Church, Chappel, or in any other place within this Realme, except hee be licen≈øed either by the Archbi≈øhop, or by the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, (where he is to be placed) vnder their handes and ≈øeales, or by one of the two Vniuer≈øities vnder their ≈øeale likewi≈øe: and except he ≈øhall fir≈øt ≈øub≈øcribe to the≈øe three Articles following, in ≈øuch maner and ≈øort as wee haue here appointed.

1 That the Kings Maie≈øtie vnder God, is the onely ≈øupreme Gouernour of this Realme,
and of all other his Highne≈ø≈øe Dominions and Countreys, a≈øwell in all Spirituall or Eccle≈øia≈øticall things or cau≈øes, as Temporall and that no forraine Prince, per≈øon, prelate, State, or potentate, hath or ought to haue any Iuri≈ødiction, power, ≈øuperioritie, preheminence, or authoritie Eccle≈øia≈øticall or Spirituall, within his Maie≈øties ≈øaid Realmes, Dominions, and Countreys.

2 That the Booke of Common prayer, and of ordering of Bi≈øhops, prie≈øts and deacons, containeth in it nothing contrary to the word of God, and that it may lawfully ≈øo be v≈øed, and that he him≈øelfe will v≈øe the forme in the ≈øaid Booke pre≈øcribed in publike prayer, and admini≈øtration of the Sacraments, and none other.

3 That he alloweth the booke of Articles of Religion agreed vpon oy the Archbi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops of both Prouinces, and the whole Cleargie in the Conuocation holden at London in the yeere of our Lord God, one thou≈øand fiue hundred ≈øixtie and two: and that he acknowledgeth all & euery the Articles therein contained being in number nine and thirty,
be≈øides the ratification, to be agreeable to the word of God.

To the≈øe three Articles who≈øoeuer will ≈øub≈øcribe, he ≈øhal for the auoyding of all ambiguities ≈øub≈øcribe in this order & fourme of words, ≈øetting downe both his chri≈øten and ≈øurname, viz. I N. N. doe willingly and ex animo ≈øub≈øcribe to the≈øe three Articles aboue mentioned, and to all things that are contained in them. And if any bi≈øhop ≈øhall ordaine, admit, or licen≈øe any as is afore≈øaid, except hee fir≈øt haue ≈øub≈øcribed in maner and fourme as here we haue appointed, he ≈øhall be ≈øu≈øpended from giuing of Orders and Licences to preach for the ≈øpace of twelue moneths. But if either of the Vniuer≈øities ≈øhall offend therein, wee leaue them to the danger of the Lawe and his Maie≈øties cen≈øure.

div.head: XXXVII. Sub≈øcription before the Dioce≈øan.
div.p:
NOne licen≈øed as is afore≈øaid, to Preach, Reade, Lecture, or Catechize, comming to re≈øide in any Dioce≈ø≈øe, ≈øhalbe permitted there to Preach, Read, Lecture, Catechize, or Mini≈øter the Sacraments, or to execute any
other Eccle≈øia≈øticall function (by what authoritie ≈øoeuer he be thereunto admitted) vnle≈ø≈øe he fir≈øt con≈øent and ≈øub≈øcribe to the three Articles before mentioned, in the pre≈øence of the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe wherin he is to preach, Read, Lecture, Cathechize or admini≈øter the Sacraments as afore≈øaid.

div.head: XXXVIII. Reuolters after Sub≈øcription, cen≈øured.
div.p: IF any Mini≈øter after he hath once ≈øub≈øcribed to the ≈øaid three Articles, ≈øhal omit to v≈øe the fourme of Prayer, or any of the Orders or Ceremonies pre≈øcribed in the Communion Booke, let him be ≈øu≈øpended: and if after a moneth he doe not reforme and ≈øubmit him≈øelfe, let him be excoÃÑmunicated: and then if he ≈øhal not ≈øubmit him≈øelf within the ≈øpace of another moneth, let him be depo≈øed froÃÑ the Mini≈øtery.

div.head: XXXIX. Cautions for In≈øtitution of Ministers into Benefices.
div.p:
NO bi≈øhop ≈øhall in≈øtitute any to a Benefice, who hath bene ordained by any other Bi≈øhop, except hee fir≈øt ≈øhew vnto him his Letters of Orders, and bring him a ≈øufficient
te≈øtimony of his former good life and behauiour, if the Bi≈øhop ≈øhall require it: and la≈øtly ≈øhall appeare vpon due examination to be worthy of his Mini≈øtery.

div.head: XL. An Oath against Symonie at institution into Benefices.
div.p:
TO auoid the dete≈øtable ≈øinne of Symony, becau≈øe buying & ≈øelling of Spiritual and Eccle≈øia≈øtical Functions, Offices, Promotions, Dignities, and Liuings is execrable before God: therefore the Archbi≈øhop and all and euery Bi≈øhop or Bi≈øhops or any other per≈øon or per≈øons, hauing authority to Admit, In≈øtitute, Collate, In≈øtall, or to confirme the election of any Archbi≈øhop, Bi≈øhop, or other per≈øon or per≈øons to any Spirituall or Eccle≈øia≈øticall function, Dignitie, Promotion, Title, Office, Iuri≈ødiction, Place, or Benefice with Cure or without Cure, or to any Eccle≈øia≈øtical liuing what≈øoeuer, ≈øhall before euery ≈øuch Admi≈øsion, In≈øtitution, Collation, In≈øtallation or Confirmation of Election, re≈øpectiuely mini≈øter to euery per≈øon hereafter to be admitted, In≈øtituted, collated, In≈øtalled, or confirmed in
or to any Archbi≈øhopricke, Bi≈øhopricke, or other Spiritual or Eccle≈øia≈øtical function, Dignitie, Promotion, Title, office, Iuri≈ødiction, Place, or Benefice with Cure or without Cure, or in or to any Eccle≈øia≈øticall liuing what≈øoeuer, this Oath in maner and forme following, the ≈øame to be taken by euery one whom it concerneth in his owne per≈øon, and not by a Proctor: I N. N. do ≈øweare, That I haue made no Symoniacall payment, contract or promi≈øe, directly or indirectly, by my ≈øelfe or by any other to my knowledge, or with my con≈øent, to any per≈øon or per≈øons what≈øoeuer, for or concerning the procuring and obtaining of this Eccle≈øia≈øticall Dignity, Place, Preferment, Office or Liuing, (re≈øpectiuely and particularly naming the ≈øame whereunto hee is to be Admitted, In≈øtituted, Collated, In≈øtalled, or Confirmed) nor will at any time hereafter perfourme or ≈øati≈øfie any ≈øuch kind of paiment, contract or promi≈øe made by any other without my knowledge or con≈øent; So helpe me God through Ie≈øus Chri≈øt.

div.head: XLI. Licen≈øes for plurality of Benefices limitted, and Re≈øidence enioyned.
div.p: NO Licen≈øe or di≈øpen≈øation for the keeping of more Benefices with Cure then one, ≈øhalbe granted to any, but ≈øuch only as ≈øhall be thought very well worthy for his learning, and very well able and ≈øufficient to di≈øcharge his duety, that is, who ≈øhall haue taken the degree of a Ma≈øter of Arts at the lea≈øt in one of the Vniuer≈øities of this Realme, and bee a publike and ≈øufficient Preacher licen≈øed. Prouided alwayes that he bee by a good and ≈øufficient caution bound to make his per≈øonall Re≈øidence in each his ≈øayd Benefices for ≈øome rea≈øonable time in euery yeere: and that the ≈øayd Benefices bee not more then thirty miles di≈øtant ≈øunder: and la≈øtly, that he haue vnder him in the Benefice where he doeth not re≈øide, a Preacher lawfully allowed, that is able ≈øufficiently to teach and in≈øtruct the people.

div.head: XLII. Re≈øidence of Deanes in their Churches.
div.p:
EVery Deane, Ma≈øter, or Warden, or chiefe Gouernour of any Cathedrall or Collegiate Church, ≈øhall be re≈øident in his ≈øaid Cathedrall or Collegiate Church foure≈øcore and ten dayes Coniunctim or Diui≈øim in euery
yeere at the lea≈øt, and then ≈øhal continue there in preaching the word of God, and keeping good ho≈øpitalitie, except he ≈øhall be otherwi≈øe let with weighty and vrgent cau≈øes to bee approoued by the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, or in any other lawfull ≈øort di≈øpen≈øed with. And when he is pre≈øent, he, with the re≈øt of the Canons or Prebendaries re≈øident, ≈øhall take ≈øpeciall care, that the Statutes and laudable Cu≈øtomes of their Church, (not being contrary to the word of God, or Prerogatiue Royall) the Statutes of this Realme being in force concerning Eccle≈øia≈øticall Order, and all other Con≈øtitutions now ≈øet foorth and confirmed by his Maie≈øties Authoritie, and ≈øuch as ≈øhall bee lawfully enioyned by the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe in his Vi≈øitation according to the Statutes and Cu≈øtomes of the ≈øame Church, or the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Lawes of this Realme, be diligently ob≈øerued, and that the Pettie Canons, Vicars chorall, and other Mini≈øters of their Church be vrged to the ≈øtudy of the holy Scriptures: and euery one of them to haue the New Te≈øtament not onely in Engli≈øh, but al≈øo in Latine.

div.head: XLIII. Deanes and Prebendaries to Preach during their Re≈øidence.
div.p: THe Deane, Ma≈øter, Warden, or chiefe Gouernour, Prebendaries and Canons in euery Cathedral & Collegiat Church, ≈øhal not onely preach there in their owne per≈øons ≈øo often as they are bound by Law, Statute, Ordinance, or Cu≈øtome; but ≈øhall likewi≈øe Preach in other Churches of the ≈øame Dioce≈ø≈øe where they are re≈øident, and e≈øpecially in tho≈øe places whence they or their Church receiue any yeerely Rents or profits. And in ca≈øe they them≈øelues bee ≈øicke, or lawfully ab≈øent, they ≈øhall ≈øub≈øtitute ≈øuch licen≈øed Preachers to ≈øupplie their turnes, as by the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe ≈øhal be thought meete to Preach in Cathedrall Churches. And if any otherwi≈øe neglect to omit or ≈øupply his cour≈øe, as is afore≈øaid, the offendor ≈øhall be puni≈øhed by the Bi≈øhop, or by him or them to whome the iuri≈ødiction of that Church appertaineth, according to the quality of the offence.

div.head: XLIIII. Prebendaries to be re≈øident vpon their Benefices.
div.p:
NO Prebendaries nor Canons in Cathedrall or Collegiate Churches, hauing one or moe Benefices with Cure, (and not beeing Re≈øidentaries in the ≈øame Cathedrall or Collegiat Churches) ≈øhall vnder colour of the ≈øayd Prebends, ab≈øent them≈øelues from their Benefices with Cure aboue the ≈øpace of one moneth in the yeere, vnle≈ø≈øe it be for ≈øome vrgent cau≈øe, and certaine time to be allowed by the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe. And ≈øuch of the ≈øaid Canons and Prebendaries as by the Ordinances of the ≈øayd Cathedrall or Collegiat Churches do ≈øtand bound to be re≈øident in the ≈øame, ≈øhall ≈øo among them≈øelues ≈øort and proportion the times of the yeere, concerning re≈øidence to bee kept in the ≈øayde Churches, as that ≈øome of them alwayes ≈øhall be per≈øonally re≈øident there: and that all tho≈øe who be, or ≈øhall be Re≈øidentiaries in any Cathedrall or Collegiat Church, ≈øhall after the dayes of their Re≈øidencie appointed by their locall Statutes or Cu≈øtomes expired, pre≈øently repaire to their Benefices, or ≈øome one of
them, or to ≈øome other Charge where the Law requireth their pre≈øence, there to di≈øcharge their dueties according to the Lawes in that ca≈øe prouided. And the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe ≈øhall ≈øee the ≈øame to be duely performed and put in execution.

div.head: XLV. Beneficed Preachers beeing re≈øident vpon their liuings to preach euery Sunday.
div.p: EVery Beneficed man allowed to bee a preacher, and re≈øiding on his Benefice, hauing no lawful impediment, ≈øhall in his owne Cure, or in ≈øome other Church or Chappell where he may conueniently neere adioyning, (where no Preacher is) preach one Sermon euery Sunday of the yeere, wherein hee ≈øhall ≈øoberly and ≈øincerely diuide the word of trueth to the glory of God, and to the be≈øt edification of the people.

div.head: XLVI. Beneficed men not Preachers to procure monethly Sermons.
div.p:
EVery beneficed man not allowed to be a Preacher, ≈øhall procure Sermons to bee preached in his Cure once in euery moneth
at the lea≈øt, by Preachers lawfully licenced, if his liuing in the iudgement of the Ordinary, will be able to beare it. And vpon euery Sunday when there ≈øhall not bee a Sermon preached in his Cure, hee or his Curate ≈øhall reade ≈øome one of the Homilies pre≈øcribed, or to be pre≈øcribed by authoritie to the intents afore≈øaid.

div.head: XLVII. Ab≈øence of Beneficed men to bee ≈øupplied by Curates that are allowed Preachers.
div.p: EVery Beneficed man licen≈øed by the Lawes of this Realme, vpon vrgent occa≈øions of other ≈øeruice not to re≈øide vpon his Benefice, ≈øhall cau≈øe his Cure to be ≈øupplied by a Curate that is a ≈øuffiicient and licen≈øed Preacher, if the worth of the Benefice wil beare it. But who≈øoeuer hath two Benefices, ≈øhall maintaine a Preacher licen≈øed, in the Benefice where he doeth not re≈øide, except he preach him≈øelfe at both of them v≈øually.

div.head: XLVIII. None to be Curates but allowed by the Bi≈øhop.
div.p:
NO Curat or Mini≈øter ≈øhall be permited to ≈øerue in any place, without Examination
and Admi≈øsion of the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe or Ordinary of the place hauing Epi≈øcopal Iuri≈ødiction, in writing vnder his hand and ≈øeale, hauing re≈øpect to the greatne≈ø≈øe of the Cure, and meetene≈ø≈øe of the party. And the ≈øaid Curates and Mini≈øters if they remooue from one Dioce≈ø≈øe to another, ≈øhal not be by any means admitted to ≈øerue without te≈øtimonie of the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, or Ordinarie of the place as afore≈øaid, whence they came, in writing, of their hone≈øty, ability, and conformitie to the Eccle≈øia≈øticall lawes of the Church of England. Nor any ≈øhall ≈øerue more then one Church or Chappel vpon one day, except that Chappell be a member of the Pari≈øh Church, or vnited thereunto: and vnle≈ø≈øe the ≈øayde Church or Chappell where ≈øuch a Mini≈øter ≈øhall ≈øerue in two places, bee not able in the iudgement of the Bi≈øhop or Ordinary as afore≈øaid to maintaine a Curate.

div.head: XLIX. Mini≈øters not allowed Preachers, may not expouÃÑd.
div.p:
NO per≈øon what≈øoeuer not examined and approued by the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, or not licen≈øed as is afore≈øaid for a ≈øufficient
or conuenient Preacher, ≈øhal take vpon him to expound in his owne Cure or el≈øewhere, any Scripture or matter of doctrine, but ≈øhall onely ≈øtudy to reade plainly and aptly (without glozing or adding) the Homilies already ≈øet foorth or hereafter to be publi≈øhed by lawfull Authoritie, for the confirmation of the true Faith, and for the good in≈øtruction and edification of the people.

div.head: L. Strangers not admitted to Preach without ≈øhewing their Licence.
div.p: NEither the Mini≈øter, Churchwardens, nor any other Officers of the Church, ≈øhall ≈øuffer any man to preach within their Churches or Chappels, but ≈øuch as by ≈øhewing their Licence to preach, ≈øhal appeare vnto them to be ≈øufficiently authorized thereunto, as is afore≈øaid.

div.head: LI. Strangers not admitted to Preach in Cathedrall Churches without ≈øufficient authoritie.
div.p:
THe Dea ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ , Pre≈øidents, & Re≈øidentiaries of any Cathedrall or Collegiate Church, ≈øhal ≈øuffer no ≈øtranger to preach vnto the
people in their Churches, except they be allowed by the Archbi≈øhop of the Prouince, or by the Bi≈øhop of the ≈øame Dioce≈ø≈øe, or by either of the Vniuer≈øities. And if any in his Sermon ≈øhal publi≈øh any Doctrine, either ≈øtrange or di≈øagreeing from the word of God, or from any of the Articles of Religion agreed vpon in the Conuocation hou≈øe Anno 1562. or from the booke of CoÃÑmon prayers: the Deane or the Re≈øidents ≈øhall by their Letters ≈øub≈øcribed with ≈øome of their hands that heard him, ≈øo ≈øoone as may be, giue notice of the ≈øame to the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, that he may determine the matter, and take ≈øuch order therein as he ≈øhall thinke conuenient.

div.head: LII. The names of ≈øtrange Preachers to bee noted in a Booke.
div.p:
THat the Bi≈øhop may vnder≈øtand (if occa≈øion ≈øo require) what Sermons are made in euery Church of his Dioce≈ø≈øe, and who pre≈øume to preach without Licence: the Churchwardens & Sidemen ≈øhall ≈øee that the names of al preachers which come to their Church from any other place, bee noted in a
booke, which they ≈øhall haue ready for that purpo≈øe: wherein euery Preacher ≈øhall ≈øub≈øcribe his name, the day when hee preached, and the name of the Bi≈øhop of whom he had Licence to preach.

div.head: LIII. No publike oppo≈øition betweene Preachers.
div.p:
IF any Preacher ≈øhall in the Pulpit particularly, or namely of purpo≈øe, impugne or confute any doctrine deliuered by any other Preacher in the ≈øame Church, or in any church neere adioyning, before he hath acquainted the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe therewith, and receiued order from him what to do in that ca≈øe, becau≈øe vpon ≈øuch publike di≈ø≈øenting and contradicting, there may grow much offence and di≈øquietne≈ø≈øe vnto the people: the Churchwardens or party grieued ≈øhall forthwith ≈øignifie the ≈øame to the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop, and not ≈øuffer the ≈øaid Preacher any more to occupy that place which he hath once abu≈øed, except hee faithfully promi≈øe to forbeare all ≈øuch matter of contention in the Church, vntill the Bi≈øhop hath taken further order therein: who ≈øhall with all conuenient ≈øpeed ≈øo proceed therein,
that publike ≈øatisfaction may bee made in the Congregation where the offence was giuen. Prouided, that if either of the parties offending doe appeale, hee ≈øhall not be ≈øuffered to preach pendente lite.

div.head: LIIII. The Licences of Preachers refu≈øing Conformitie, to be voyd.
div.p: IF any man licenced heretofore to preach, by any Archbi≈øhop, Bi≈øhop, or by either of the Vniuer≈øities, ≈øhall at any time from henceforth refu≈øe to conforme him≈øelfe to the Lawes, Ordinances, and Rites Eccle≈øia≈øticall e≈øtabli≈øhed in the Church of England, he ≈øhall be admoni≈øhed by the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, or Ordinary of the place, to ≈øubmit him≈øelfe to the v≈øe and due exerci≈øe of the ≈øame. And if after ≈øuch admonition, he doe not conforme him≈øelfe within the ≈øpace of one moneth, We determine and decree, That the licence of euery ≈øuch Preacher ≈øhall thereupon bee vtterly voyde and of none effect.

div.head: LV. The forme of a Prayer to bee v≈øed by Preachers before their Sermons.
div.p:
BEfore all Sermons, Lectures, and Homilies, the Preachers & Mini≈øters ≈øhall moue the people to ioine with them in prayer in this forme, or to this effect, as briefly as conueniently they may. Ye ≈øhal pray for Chri≈øts holy Catholike Church, that is, for the whole Congregation of Chri≈øtian people di≈øper≈øed throughout the whole world, and e≈øpecially for the Churches of England, Scotland, and Ireland. And herein I require you mo≈øt e≈øpecially to pray for the Kings mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie, our Soueraigne Lord IAMES, King of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, Defendour of the Faith, & Supreme Gouernour in the≈øe his Realmes, and all other his Dominions and Countries, ouer all per≈øons, in all cau≈øes, a≈øwell Eccle≈øia≈øticall as Temporall. Ye ≈øhall al≈øo pray for our gracious Queene ANNE, the Noble Prince HENRY, and the re≈øt of the King and Queenes Royall I≈ø≈øue. Ye ≈øhall al≈øo pray for the Mini≈øters of Gods holy word & Sacraments, a≈øwell Archbi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops, as other Pa≈øtours and Curates. Ye ≈øhall al≈øo pray for the Kings mo≈øt honourable Coun≈øell, and for all the Nobilitie and Magi≈øtrates
of this Realme, that all & euery of the≈øe in their ≈øeuerall Callings, may ≈øerue truely and painefully to the glory of God, and the edifying and well gouerning of his people, remembring the accompt that they mu≈øt make. Al≈øo yee ≈øhall pray for the whole Commons of this Realme, that they may liue in true Faith and feare of God, in humble obedience to the King, and brotherly charitie one to another. Finally, let vs prai≈øe God for all tho≈øe which are departed out of this life in the Faith of Chri≈øt, and pray vnto God that wee may haue grace to direct our liues after their good example: that this life ended, wee may be made partakers with them of the glorious Re≈øurrection in the life Euerla≈øting, alwayes concluding with the Lords prayer.

div.head: LVI. Preachers and Lecturers to reade diuine Seruice and admini≈øter the Sacraments twi≈øe a yeere at the lea≈øt.
div.p:
EVery Mini≈øter being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a Benefice that hath Cure and Charge of ≈øoules, although he chiefly attend to preaching, and hath a Curate vnder him to execute the other
duties, which are to be performed for him in the Church, and likewi≈øe euery other ≈øtipendarie Preacher that readeth any Lecture, or Catechizeth, or Preacheth in any Church or Chappell, ≈øhall twi≈øe at the lea≈øt euery yeere reade him≈øelfe the diuine Seruice, vpon two ≈øeuerall Sundayes, publikely and at the v≈øuall times, both in the Forenoone and Afternoone in the Church which he ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth, or where he Readeth, Catechizeth, or Preacheth as is afore≈øaid, and ≈øhal likewi≈øe as often in euery yeere admini≈øter the Sacraments of Bapti≈øme (if there be any to be baptized) & of the Lords Supper, in ≈øuch maner & forme, and with the ob≈øeruation of all such Rites and Ceremonies as are pre≈øcribed by the booke of Common prayer in that behalfe: which if hee doe not accordingly performe, then ≈øhall he that is po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a Benefice (as before) bee ≈øu≈øpended: and he thatis but aReader, Preacher, or Catechizer, be remoued from his place by the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, vntil he or they ≈øhal ≈øubmit them≈øelues to performe all the ≈øaid duties, in ≈øuch mater and ‚Ä¢ ort as before is pre≈øcribed.

div.head: LVII. The Sacraments not to be refu≈øed at the hands of vnpreaching Mini≈øters.
div.p:
WHereas diuers Per≈øons ≈øeduced by fal≈øe Teachers, doe refu≈øe to haue their children baptized by a Mini≈øter that is no Preacher, and to receiue the holy Communion at his hands in the ≈øame re≈øpect, as though the vertue of tho≈øe Sacraments did depend vpon his ability to preach: Fora≈ømuch as the doctrine both of Bapti≈øme and of the Lords Supper is ≈øufficiently ≈øet downe in the booke of Common prayer to bee v≈øed at the admini≈øtration of the ≈øaid Sacraments, as nothing can be added vnto it that is material and nece≈ø≈øary: We doe require and charge euery ≈øuch per≈øon ≈øeduced as afore≈øayd, to reforme that their wilfulne≈ø≈øe, and to ≈øubmit him≈øelfe to the order of the Church in that behalfe, both the ≈øaid Sacraments being equally effectual, whether they be mini≈øtred by a Mini≈øter that is no Preacher, or by one that is a Preacher. And if any hereafter ≈øhal offend herein, or leaue their owne Pari≈øh Churches in that re≈øpect, and Communicate or cau≈ø ‚Ä¢ their children
to be Baptized in other Pari≈øhes abroad, and will not bee mooued thereby to reforme that their error and vnlawfull cour≈øe: let them be pre≈øented to the Ordinarie of the place by the Mini≈øter, Churchwardens, and Sidemen or Que≈øtmen of the Pari≈øhes where they dwel, and there receiue ≈øuch puni≈øhment by Eccle≈øia≈øticall cen≈øures, as ≈øuch ob≈øtinacie doth worthily de≈øerue: that is, Let them (per≈øi≈øting in their wilfulne≈ø≈øe) be ≈øu≈øpended, and then after a moneths further ob≈øtinacie, Excommunicated. And likewi≈øe if any Par≈øon, Vicar, or Curate, ≈øhal after the publi≈øhing hereof, either receiue to the Communion any ≈øuch per≈øons which are not of his owne Church & Pari≈øh, or ≈øhall Baptize any of their children, thereby ≈øtrengthening them in their ≈øaid errours, Let him bee ≈øu≈øpended, and not relea≈øed thereof, vntill hee doe faithfully promi≈øe that hee will not afterwards offend therein.

div.head: LVIII. Mini≈øters reading Diuine Seruice, and Admini≈øtring the Sacraments, to weare Surpli≈øses, and Graduats therewithall Hoods.
div.p: EVery Mini≈øter ≈øaying the publike Praiers, or mini≈øtring the Sacraments or other Rites of the Church, ≈øhall weare a decent and comely Surpli≈ø≈øe with ≈øleeues, to be prouided at the charge of the Pari≈øh. And if any que≈øtion ari≈øe touching the matter, decencie, or comline≈ø≈øe thereof, the ≈øame ≈øhalbe decided by the di≈øcretion of the Ordinary. Furthermore ≈øuch Mini≈øters as are Graduats, ≈øhall weare vpon their Surpli≈ø≈øes at ≈øuch times, ≈øuch Hoods as by the orders of the Vniuer≈øities are agreeable to their degrees, which no Mini≈øter ≈øhall weare (being no Graduat) vnder paine of ≈øu≈øpen≈øion. Notwith≈øtanding it ≈øhalbe lawfull for ≈øuch Mini≈øters as are not Graduats, to weare vpon their Surpli≈ø≈øes in ≈øtead of Hoods, ≈øome decent Tippet of black, ≈øo it be not ≈øilke.

div.head: LIX. Mini≈øters to Catechize euery Sunday.
div.p:
EVery Par≈øon, Vicar, or Curate, vpon euery Sunday and Holy day before Euening prayer, ≈øhall for halfe an houre or more, examine and in≈øtruct the youth and ignorant per≈øons of his Pari≈øh in the ten Commandements, the Articles of the Beliefe, and in the
Lords prayer: and ≈øhall diligently heare, in≈øtruct, & teach them the Catechi≈øme ≈øet forth in the Booke of Common prayer. And all Fathers, Mothers, Ma≈øters, and Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øes, ≈øhall cau≈øe their children, ≈øeruants, and apprentices, which haue not learned the Catechi≈øme, to come to the Church at the time appointed, obediently to heare, and to bee ordered by the Mini≈øter, vntill they haue learned the ≈øame. And if any Mini≈øter neglect his duetie herein, let him bee ≈øharpely reprooued vpon the fir≈øt complaint, and true notice thereof giuen to the Bi≈øhop or Ordinarie of the place. If after ≈øubmitting him≈øelfe, hee ≈øhall wilfully offend therein againe, let him be ≈øu≈øpended. If ≈øo the third time, there being little hope that he will bee therein reformed, then Excommunicated, and ≈øo remaine vntil he will be reformed. And likewi≈øe if any of the ≈øaide Fathers, Mothers, Ma≈øters, or Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øes, Children, Seruants, or Apprentices ≈øhall neglect their dueties, as the one ≈øort in not cau≈øing them to come, and the other in refu≈øing to learne as afore≈øaid, Let them bee ≈øu≈øpended by their Ordinaries, (if they be not children) and if they ≈øo per≈øi≈øt by
the ≈øpace of a moneth, then let them bee Excommunicated.

div.head: LX. Confirmation to be performed once in three yeeres.
div.p: FOra≈ømuch as it hath beene a ≈øolemne, ancient, & laudable Cu≈øtome in the Church of God, continued from the Apo≈øtles times, that all Bi≈øhops ≈øhould lay their hands vpon children Baptized and in≈øtructed in the Catechi≈øme of Chri≈øtian Religion, praying ouer them, and ble≈øsing them, which wee commonly call Confirmation, and that this holy action hath beene accu≈øtomed in the Church in former ages, to be performed in the Bi≈øhops Vi≈øitation euery third yeere: We will and appoint, that euery Bi≈øhop, or his Suffragan in his accu≈øtomed Vi≈øitation, do in his owne per≈øon carefully ob≈øerue the ≈øaid Cu≈øtome. And if in that yeere by rea≈øon of ≈øome infirmitie, he be not able per≈øonally to Vi≈øit, then he ≈øhal not omit the execution of that duetie of Confirmation the next yeere after, as he may conueniently.

div.head: LXI. Mini≈øters to prepare children for Confirmation.
div.p: EVery Mini≈øter that hath Cure and charge of ≈øoules, for the better accompli≈øhing of the Orders pre≈øcribed in the Booke of Common prayer concerning Confirmation, ≈øhall take ≈øuch e≈øpeciall care as that none may be pre≈øented to the Bi≈øhop for him to lay his hands vpon, but ≈øuch as can render an account of their Faith according to the Catechi≈øme in the ≈øaid Booke contained. And when the Bi≈øhop ≈øhall a≈ø≈øigne any time for the performance of that part of his duty, euery ≈øuch Mini≈øter ≈øhall v≈øe his be≈øt endeuour to prepare and make able, and likewi≈øe to procure as many as he can to be then brought, and by the Bi≈øhop to be confirmed.

div.head: LXII. Mini≈øters not to marrie any per≈øons without Bannes or Licence.
div.p:
NO Mini≈øter vpon paine of ≈øu≈øpen≈øion per triennium ip≈øo facto, ≈øhall celebrate Matrimonie betweene any per≈øons without a Facultie or Licence granted by ≈øome of the per≈øons in the≈øe our Con≈øtitutions expre≈ø≈øed,
except the Bannes of Matrimonie haue bene fir≈øt publi≈øhed three ≈øeueral Sundaies or Holy dayes in the time of diuine Seruice in the Pari≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ churches and Chappels where the ≈øaide parties dwel, according to the booke of Common prayer. Neither ≈øhall any Mini≈øter vpon the like paine vnder any pretence what≈øoeuer, ioyne any per≈øons ≈øo licenced in Marriage at any vn≈øea≈øonable times, but onely betweene the houres of eight and twelue in the forenoone, nor in any priuate place, but either in the ≈øaid Churches or Chappels where one of them dwelleth, and likewi≈øe in time of Diuine Seruice: nor when Bannes are thrice asked (and no Licence in that re≈øpect nece≈ø≈øary) before the Parents or Gouernours of the parties to be married, being vnder the age of twentie and one yeeres, ≈øhall either per≈øonally, or by ≈øufficient te≈øtimonie, ≈øignifie to him their con≈øents giuen to the ≈øaid Marriage.

div.head: LXIII. Mini≈øters of exempt Churches not to Marry without Bannes or Licence.
div.p:
EVery Mini≈øter who ≈øhal hereafter celebrate Marriage betwixt any per≈øons contrary to
our ≈øaid Con≈øtitutions, or any part of them, vnder colour of any peculiar Libertie or Priuiledge claimed to appertaine to certaine Churches and Chappels, ≈øhall be ≈øu≈øpended per triennium, by the Ordinarie of the place where the offence ≈øhalbe committed. And if any ≈øuch Mini≈øter ≈øhall afterwards remooue from the place where he hath committed that fault before he be ≈øu≈øpended, as is afore≈øaid, then ≈øhall the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, or Ordinarie of the place where he remaineth, vpon Certificat vnder the Hand and Seale of the other Ordinarie from who≈øe Iuri≈ødiction hee remooued, execute that cen≈øure vpon him.

div.head: LXIIII. Mini≈øters ≈øolemnly to bid Holy dayes.
div.p:
EVery Par≈øon, Vicar, or Curate ≈øhall in his ≈øeuerall charge declare to the people euery Sunday at the time appointed in the Communion Booke, whether there bee any Holy dayes or Fa≈øting dayes the weeke following. And if any doe hereafter wittingly offend herein, and beeing once admoni≈øhed thereof by his Ordinary, ≈øhall againe omit that duetie: let him be cen≈øured according to
Law, vntill hee ≈øubmit him≈øelfe to the due performance of it.

div.head: LXV. Mini≈øters ≈øolemnly to denounce Recu≈øants and Excommunicats.
div.p:
ALl Ordinaries ≈øhall in their ≈øeuerall Iuri≈ødictions carefully ≈øee & giue order, that a≈øwell tho≈øe who for ob≈øtinate refu≈øing to frequent diuine Seruice e≈øtabli≈øhed by publike authority within this Realme of England, as tho≈øe al≈øo (e≈øpecially of the better ≈øort and condition) who for notorious contumacie or other notable crimes ≈øtand lawfully excommunicate, (vnle≈ø≈øe within three moneths immediatly after the ≈øaid ≈øentence of Excommunication pronounced again≈øt them, they reforme them≈øelues, and obtaine the benefit of Ab≈øolution) bee euery ≈øixe moneths en≈øuing, a≈øwell in the Pari≈øh Church, as in the Cathedrall Church of the Dioce≈ø≈øe in which they remaine, by the Mini≈øter openly in time of Diuine Seruice vpon ≈øome Sunday denounced and declared Excommunicate, that others may be thereby both admoni≈øhed to refraine their company and ≈øociety, and excited the rather
to procure out a Writ De excommunicate capiendo, thereby to bring and reduce them into due order and obedience. Likewi≈øe the Regi≈øter of euery Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court, ≈øhal yeerely betweene Michaelmas and Chri≈øtmas, duely certifie the Archbi≈øhop of the Prouince of all and ≈øinguler the premi≈ø≈øes afore≈øaid.

div.head: LXVI. Miui≈øters to conferre with Recu≈øants.
div.p:
EVery Mini≈øter being a Preacher, and hauing any Popi≈øh Recu≈øant or Recu≈øants in his Pari≈øh, and thought fit by the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, ≈øhall labour diligently wi ‚Ä¢ h them from time to time, thereby to recl ‚Ä¢ ime them from their errours. And if he be „Äà‚óä„Äâ Preacher, or not ≈øuch a Preacher, then hee ≈øhall procure, if he can po≈øsibly, ≈øome that are Preachers ≈øo qualified, to take paines with them for that purpo≈øe. If he can procure none, then he ≈øhall informe the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe thereof, who ≈øhal not only appoint ≈øome neighbour Preacher or Preachers adioyning „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ labour vpon them, but him≈øelfe al≈øo „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ important affaires wil permit him) ≈øhal „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ is be≈øt endeuour by in≈øtruction, per≈øwa≈øion,
and all good meanes he can deui≈øe to reclaime both them and all other within his Dioce≈ø≈øe ≈øo affected.

div.head: LXVII. Mini≈øters to vi≈øite the ≈øicke.
div.p: WHen any per≈øon is dangerou≈øly ≈øicke in any Pari≈øh, the Mini≈øter or Curate (hauing knowledge thereof) ≈øhal re≈øort vnto him or her (if the di≈øea≈øe bee not knowen or probably ≈øu≈øpected to bee infectious) to in≈øtruct and comfort them in their di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, according to the order of the Communion booke, if he be no Preacher: or if hee be a Preacher, then as he ≈øhall thinke mo≈øt needfull and conuenient. And when any is pa≈øsing out of this life, a Bell ≈øhall bee tolled, and the Mini≈øter ≈øhall not then ≈ølacke to doe his la≈øt duetie. And after the parties death (if it ≈øo fall out) there ≈øhal be rung no more but one ≈øhort peale, and one other before the buriall, and one other after the buriall.

div.head: LXVIII. Mini≈øters not to refu≈øe to chri≈øten or bury.
div.p:
NO Mini≈øter ≈øhal refu≈øe or delay t ‚Ä¢ chri≈øten any child according to the forme of the
booke of Common prayer, that is brought to the Church to him vpon Sundayes or Holydayes to be chri≈øtened, or to bury any corps that is brought to the Church or Churchyard (conuenient warning being giuen him thereof before) in ≈øuch manner and forme as is pre≈øcribed in the ≈øaid booke of Common prayer. And if he ≈øhall refu≈øe to chri≈øten the one, or bury the other, except the party decea≈øed were denounced excommunicated maiori excommunicatione, for ≈øome grieuous and notorious crime, (and no man able to te≈øtifie of his repentance) he ≈øhalbe ≈øu≈øpended by the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe from his Mini≈øterie by the ≈øpace of three moneths.

div.head: LXIX. Mini≈øters not to deferre Chri≈øtening, if the childe be in danger.
div.p:
IF any Mini≈øter beeing duely without any maner of collu≈øion, informed of the weakne≈ø≈øe and danger of death of any Infant vnbaptized in his Pari≈øh, and thereupon de≈øired to go or come to the place where the ≈øaid Infant remaineth to baptize the ≈øame, ≈øhal either wilfully refu≈øe ≈øo to doe, or of purpo≈øe, or of
gro≈ø≈øe negligence ≈øhall ≈øo deferre the time, as when he might conueniently haue re≈øorted to the place, and haue baptized the ≈øaid Infant, it dieth through ≈øuch his default vnbaptized: the ≈øaid Mini≈øter ≈øhall be ≈øu≈øpended for three moneths, and before his re≈øtitution ≈øhall acknowledge his fault, and promi≈øe before his Ordinarie, that hee will not wittingly incurre the like againe. Prouided, that where there is a Curate or a Sub≈øtitute, this Con≈øtitution ≈øhall not extend to the Par≈øon or Vicar him≈øelfe, but to the Curate or Sub≈øtitute pre≈øent.

div.head: LXX. Mini≈øters to keepe a Regi≈øter of Chri≈øtnings, Weddings, and Burials.
div.p:
IN euery Pari≈øh Church and Chappell within this Realme, ≈øhall be prouided one parchment Booke at the charge of the Pari≈øh, wherein ≈øhall be written the day and yeere of euery Chri≈øtning, Wedding, and Buriall, which haue bene in that Pari≈øh ≈øince the time that the Law was fir≈øt made in that behalfe, ≈øo farre as the ancient Bookes thereof can be procured, but e≈øpecially ≈øince the beginning of the Raigne of the late Qneene. And for the ≈øafe
