keeping of the ≈øaid booke, the Churchwardens at the charge of the Pari≈øh, ≈øhall prouide one ≈øure Coffer with three lockes & keyes, whereof the one to remaine with the Mini≈øter, and the other two with the Churchwardens ≈øeuerally, ≈øo that neither the Mini≈øter without the two Churchwardens, nor the Churchwardens without the Mini≈øter, ≈øhall at any time take that Booke out of the ≈øaid Coffer. And henceforth vpon euery Sabboth day, immediatly after Morning or Euening prayer, the Mini≈øter and Churchwardens ≈øhal take the ≈øaid parchment Booke out of the ≈øaid Coffer, and the Mini≈øter in the pre≈øence of the Churchwardens ≈øhall write and record in the ≈øaid Booke, the names of all per≈øons Chri≈øtned, together with the names and ≈øurnames of their Parents, and al≈øo the names of all per≈øons Married and Buried in that pari≈øh, in the weeke before, and the day and yeere of euery ≈øuch Chri≈øtning, Marriage, and Buriall: And that done, they ≈øhal lay vp that Booke in the Coffer as before: and the Mini≈øter and Churchwardens vnto euery page of that Booke, when it ≈øhall be filled with ≈øuch in≈øcriptions, ≈øhall ≈øub≈øcribe their
names. And the Churchwardens ≈øhall once euery yeere within one Moneth after the fiue and twentieth day of March, tran≈ømit vnto the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, or his Chancellor, a true Copy of the names of al per≈øons Chri≈øtned, Married, or Buried in their Pari≈øh in the yeere before (ended the ≈øaid fiue and twentieth day of March) and the certaine dayes and moneths in which euery ≈øuch Chri≈øtning, Marriage and Buriall was had, to be ≈øub≈øcribed with the hands of the ≈øaid Mini≈øter & Churchwardens, to the end the ≈øame may faithfully bee pre≈øerued in the Regi≈øtrie of the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop: which Certificat ≈øhalbe receiued without Fee. And if the Mini≈øter or Churchwardens ≈øhall be negligent in performance of any thing herein contained, it ≈øhall be lawfull for the Bi≈øhop or his Chancellor to conuent them, and proceede again≈øt euery of them as contemners of this our Con≈øtitution.

div.head: LXXI. Mini≈øters not to Preach or admini≈øter the Communion in priuate hou≈øes.
div.p:
NO Mini≈øter ≈øhall Preach or admini≈øter the holy Communion in any priuate hou≈øe,
except it be in times of nece≈øsitie, when any being either ≈øo impotent, as hee cannot goe to the Church, or very dangerou≈øly ≈øicke, are de≈øirous to bee partakers of that holy Sacrament, vnder paine of ≈øu≈øpen≈øion for the fir≈øt offence, and Excommunication for the ≈øecond. Prouided that hou≈øes are here reputed for Priuate hou≈øes, wherein are no Chappels dedicated and allowed by the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Lawes of this Realme. And prouided al≈øo vnder the paine before expre≈ø≈øed, that no Chapleins doe Preach or admini≈øter the Communion in any other places, but in the Chappels of the ≈øaid hou≈øes, and that al≈øo they do the ≈øame very ≈øeldome vpon Sundayes and holy dayes. So that both the Lords and Ma≈øters of the ≈øaid hou≈øes and their families ≈øhall at other times re≈øort to their owne Pari≈øh Churches, and there receiue the holy Communion at the lea≈øt once euery yeere.

div.head: LXXII. Mini≈øters not to appoint publike or priuate Fa≈øts, or Prophe≈øies, or to exorcize, but by authority.
div.p:
NO Mini≈øter or Mini≈øters ≈øhall without the Licence and direction of the Bi≈øhop of
the Dioce≈ø≈øe fir≈øt obtained and had vnder his Hand and Seale, appoint or keepe any ≈øolemne Fa≈øts, either publikely or in any priuate hou≈øes, other then ≈øuch as by Law are, or by publike authoritie ≈øhall be appointed, nor ≈øhall be wittingly pre≈øent at any of them, vnder paine of Su≈øpen≈øion for the fir≈øt fault, of Excommunication for the ≈øecond, and of Depo≈øition from the Mini≈øterie for the third. Neither ≈øhall any Mini≈øter not licen≈øed, as is afore≈øaide, pre≈øume to appoint or hold any meetings for Sermons, commonly termed by ≈øome, Prophe≈øies or Exerci≈øes, in Market townes or other places, vnder the ≈øaid paines: Nor without ≈øuch Licen≈øe to attempt vpon any pretence what≈øoeuer, either of Po≈ø≈øe≈øsion or Qb≈øe≈øsion, by fa≈øting and prayer to ca≈øt out any deuill or deuils, vnder paine of the imputation of Impo≈øture, or Co≈øenage, and Depo≈øition from the Mini≈øterie.

div.head: LXXIII. Mini≈øters not to hold priuate Conuenticles.
div.p:
FOra≈ømuch as all Conuenticles and ≈øecret meetings of Prie≈øtes and Mini≈øters, haue bene euer iu≈øtly accompted very hurtfull
to the State of the Church wherein they liue: We doe now ordaine and con≈øtitute, That no Prie≈øts or Mini≈øters of the word of God, nor any other per≈øons ≈øhall meete together in any priuate hou≈øe or el≈øewhere to con≈øult vpon any matter or cour≈øe to bee taken by them, or vpon their motion or direction by any other, which may any way tend to the impeaching or deprauing of the doctrine of the Church of England, or of the Booke of Common praier, or of any part of the gouernment and Di≈øcipline now e≈øtabli≈øhed in the Church of England, vnder pain of ExcoÃÑmunication ip≈øo facto.

div.head: LXXIIII. Decencie in apparell enioyned to Ministers.
div.p:
THe true, ancient and flourishing Churches of Chri≈øt being euer de≈øirous that their Prelacie and Cleargie might be had as well in outward reuerence, as otherwi≈øe regarded for the worthine≈ø≈øe of their Mini≈øtery, did thinke it fit by a pre≈øcript forme of decent and comely Apparell, to haue them knowen to the people, and thereby to receiue the honor and e≈øtimation due to the ≈øpecial Me≈ø≈øengers and Mini≈øters of Almighty God. Wee
therefore following their graue iudgement, and the ancient Cu≈øtome of the Church of England, and hoping that in time new fanglene≈ø≈øe of Apparell in ≈øome factious per≈øons will die of it ≈øelfe, do con≈øtitute and appoint, That the Archbi≈øhop and Bi≈øhops, ≈øhall not intermit to v≈øe the accu≈øtomed Apparel of their degrees. Likewi≈øe all Deanes, Ma≈øters of Colledges, Archdeacons, and Prebendaries in Cathedrall and Collegiate Churches, (beeing Prie≈øts or Deacons) Doctors in Diuinitie, Law, and Phi≈øicke, Bachelers in Diuinitie, Ma≈øters of Arts, and Bachelers of Lawe hauing any Eccle≈øia≈øticall liuing, ≈øhall v≈øually weare Gownes with ≈øtanding collers, and ≈øleeues ≈øtreight at the hands, or wide ≈øleeues as is v≈øed in the Vniuer≈øities, with Hoods or Tippets of Silke or Sarcenet, and ≈øquare Caps. And that all other Mini≈øters, admitted or to be admitted into that Function, ≈øhall al≈øo v≈øually weare the like Apparell, as is afore≈øaid, except Tippets onely. We doe further in like maner ordaine, That all the ≈øaid Eccle≈øia≈øticall per≈øons aboue mentioned, ≈øhall v≈øually weare in their iourneys Cloakes with ≈øleeues, commonly called
Prie≈øts Cloaks without gards, welts, long Buttons, or cuts. And no Eccle≈øia≈øtical per≈øon ≈øhall weare any Coife, or wrought Nightcap, but onely plaine Nightcaps of blacke ≈øilke, Satten, or Veluet. In all which particulars concerning the Apparell here pre≈øcribed, our meaning is not to attribute any holine≈ø≈øe or ≈øpeciall worthine≈ø≈øe to the ≈øaid garments, but for decencie, grauitie and order, as is before ≈øpecified. In priuate hou≈øes, and in their Studies, the ≈øaid per≈øons Eccle≈øia≈øticall may v≈øe any comely and Schollerlike Apparel. Prouided, that it be not cut or pinckt, and that in publike they goe not in their Dublet and Ho≈øe, without Coats or Ca≈ø≈øocks: and al≈øo that they weare not any light coloured Stockins. Likewi≈øe poore beneficed men and Curats (not being able to prouide them≈øelues long Gownes) may goe in ≈øhort Gownes, of the fa≈øhion afore≈øaid.

div.head: LXXV. Sober conuer≈øation required in Ministers.
div.p:
NO Eccle≈øia≈øtical per≈øons ≈øhal at any time, other then for their hone≈øt nece≈øsities, re≈øort to any Tauernes or Alehou≈øes, neither ≈øhall they board or lodge in any ≈øuch
places. Furthermore, they ≈øhal not giue them≈øelues to any ba≈øe or ≈øeruile labour, or to drinking or riot, ≈øpending their time idlely by day or by night, playing at Dice, Cardes, or Tables, or any other vnlawfull game: but at all times conuenient, they ≈øhall heare or reade ≈øomewhat of the holy Scriptures, or ≈øhall occupie them≈øelues with ≈øome other hone≈øt ≈øtudie or exerci≈øe, alwayes doing the things which ≈øhall appertaine to hone≈øtie, and endeuouring to profit the Church of God, hauing alwayes in minde that they ought to excell all others in puritie of life, and ≈øhould bee examples to the people to liue well and Chri≈øtianly vnder paine of Eccle≈øia≈øticall cen≈øures to be inflicted with ≈øeueritie, according to the qualities of their offences.

div.head: LXXVI. Ministers at no time to for≈øake their Calling.
div.p:
NO man being admitted a Deacon or Mini≈øter, ≈øhall from thenceforth voluntarily relinqui≈øh the ≈øame, nor afterward v≈øe him≈øelfe in the cour≈øe of his life, as a Lay man, vpon paine of Excommunication. And the names of all ≈øuch men ≈øo for≈øaking ther
calling, the Church-wardens of the Pari≈øh where they dwell ≈øhall pre≈øent to the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, or to the Ordinarie of the place, hauing Epi≈øcopall Iuri≈ødiction.

div.head: ‚ùßSchoolema≈øters.
LXXVII. None to teach Schoole without Licence.
div.p: NO man ≈øhal teach either in publike Schoole, or priuate hou≈øe, but ≈øuch as ≈øhall bee allowed by the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, or Ordinarie of the place vnder his Hand and Seale, being found meete a≈øwell for his learning and dexteritie in teaching, as for ≈øober and hone≈øt conuer≈øation, and al≈øo for right vnder≈øtanding of Gods true Religion, and al≈øo except he ≈øhall fir≈øt ≈øub≈øcribe to the fir≈øt and third Articles afore mentioned ≈øimply, and to the two fir≈øt clau≈øes of the ≈øecond Article.

div.head: LXXVIII. Curats de≈øirous to teach, to bee licenced before others.
div.p: IN what Pari≈øh Church or Chappell ≈øoeuer there is a Curate which is a Ma≈øter of Arts, or Bacheler of Arts, or is otherwi≈øe well able to teach youth, and will willingly ≈øo doe, for the better increa≈øe of his liuing, and trayning vp of children in Principles of true Religion: We will and ordaine, That a Licence to teach youth of the Pari≈øh where he ≈øerueth, be granted to none by the Ordinarie of that place, but onely to the ≈øaide Curate. Prouided alwayes, That this Con≈øtitution ≈øhall not extend to any Pari≈øh or Chappell in countrey Townes, where there is a publike Schoole founded already: In which ca≈øe wee thinke it not meete to allow any to teach Grammer, but onely him that is allowed for the ≈øaid publike Schoole.

div.head: LXXIX. The duetie of Schoolemasters.
div.p:
ALl Schoolema≈øters ≈øhall teach in Engli≈øh or Latine, as the children are able to beare, the larger or ≈øhorter Catechi≈øme
heretofore by publike authoritie ≈øet foorth. And as often as any Sermon ≈øhall bee vpon Holy and Fe≈øtiuall dayes, within the Pari≈øh where they teach, they ≈øhall bring their Schollers to the Church where ≈øuch Sermon ≈øhall bee made, and there ≈øee them quietly and ≈øoberly behaue them≈øelues, and ≈øhall examine them at times conuenient after their returne, what they haue borne away of ≈øuch Sermons. Vpon other dayes, and at other times they ≈øhal traine them vp with ≈øuch ≈øentences of holy Scripture, as ≈øhall bee mo≈øt expedient to induce them to all godline≈ø≈øe: and they ≈øhall teach the Grammer ≈øet forth by King HENRY the eight, and continued in the times of King EDVVARD the ≈øixt, and Queene ELIZABETH of noble memory, and none other. And if any Schoolema≈øter being licenced, and hauing ≈øub≈øcribed, as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall offend in any of the premi≈ø≈øes, or either ≈øpeake, write, or teach again≈øt any thing whereunto he hath formerly ≈øub≈øcribed, (if vpon admonition by the Ordinary he do not amend and reforme him≈øelfe) let him bee ≈øu≈øpended from teaching Schoole any longer.

div.head: ¬∂Things appertaining to Churches.
LXXX. The great Bible and Booke of Common prayer to be had in euery Church.
div.p: THe Church-wardens or Que≈øtmen of euery Church & Chappell ≈øhall at the charge of the Pari≈øh prouide the Booke of Common prayer lately explaned in ≈øome few points by his Maie≈øties authoritie according to the Lawes and his Highne≈ø≈øe prerogatiue in that behalfe, and that with all conuenient ≈øpeed, but at the furthe≈øt within two moneths after the publi≈øhing of the≈øe our Con≈øtitutions. And if any Pari≈øhes bee yet vnfurni≈øhed of the Bible of the large≈øt volume, or of the Bookes of Homilies allowed by Authoritie: the ≈øaid Church-wardens ≈øhall within conuenient time prouide the ≈øame at the like charge of the Pari≈øh.

div.head: LXXXI. A Font of ≈øtone for Bapti≈øme in euery Church.
div.p: ACcording to a former Con≈øtitution, too much neglected in many places, wee appoint, That there ≈øhalbe a Font of ≈øtone in euery Church and Chappell where Bapti≈øme is to be mini≈øtred: the ≈øame to bee ≈øet in the ancient v≈øuall places. In which onely Font the Mini≈øter ≈øhall baptize publikely.

div.head: LXXXII. A decent Communion Table in euery Church.
div.p:
WHereas we haue no doubt but that in all Churches within the Realme of England, conuenient and decent Tables are prouided, and placed for the celebration of the holy Communion, we appoint that the ≈øame Tables ≈øhall from time to time bee kept and repaired in ≈øufficient and ≈øeemely manner, and couered in time of diuine Seruice with a Carpet of Silke or other decent ≈øtuffe thought meet by the Ordinarie of the place, if any que≈øtion be made of it, and with a faire Linnen cloth at the time of the mini≈øtration as becommeth that Table, and ≈øo ≈øtand, ≈øauing
when the ≈øaid holy Communion is to bee admini≈øtred. At which time the ≈øame ≈øhall bee placed in ≈øo good ≈øort within the Church or Chancell, as thereby the Mini≈øter may be more conueniently heard of the Communicants in his prayer and mini≈øtration, and the Communicants al≈øo more conueniently and in more number may communicate with the ≈øaid Mini≈øter: and that the ten Commandements be ≈øet vpon the Ea≈øt ende of euery Church and Chappell where the people may be≈øt ≈øee and reade the ≈øame, and other cho≈øen Sentences written vpon the walles of the ≈øaid Churches and Chappels in places conuenient: and likewi≈øe that a conuenient ≈øeate bee made for the Mini≈øter to reade Seruice in. All the≈øe to bee done at the charge of the Pari≈øh.

div.head: LXXXIII. A pulpit to be prouided in euery Church.
div.p:
THe Churchwardens or Que≈øtmen at the common charge of the Pari≈øhioners in euery Church, ≈øhall prouide a comely and decent Pulpit to bee ≈øet in a conuenient place within the ≈øame by the di≈øcretion of the Ordinarie of the place, if any que≈øtion doe
ari≈øe, and to be there ≈øeemely kept for the preaching of Gods word.

div.head: LXXXIIII. A Che≈øt for Almes in euery Church.
div.p:
THe Churchwardens ≈øhall prouide and haue within three moneths after the publi≈øhing of the≈øe con≈øtitutions, a ≈øtrong Che≈øt, with a hole in the vpper part thereof, to be prouided at the charge of the Pari≈øh (if there be none ≈øuch already prouided) hauing three keyes. Of which one ≈øhall remaine in the cu≈øtody of the Par≈øon, Vicar, or Curat, and the other two in the cu≈øtody of the Churchwardens for the time beeing, which Che≈øt they ≈øhall ≈øet and fa≈øten in the mo≈øt conuenient place, to the intent the Pari≈øhioners may put into it their Almes for their poore neighbours. And the Par≈øon, Vicar, or Curate ≈øhall diligently from time to time, and e≈øpecially when men make their Te≈øtaments, call vpon, exhort, and mooue their neighbours to conferre, and giue as they may well ≈øpare to the ≈øaid Che≈øt, declaring vnto them, that whereas heretofore they haue bene diligent to be≈øtow much ≈øub≈øtance, otherwi≈øe then God commaunded,
vpon ≈øuper≈øtitious v≈øes: now they ought at this time to be much more ready to helpe the poore and needy, knowing that to relieue the poore, is a ≈øacrifice which plea≈øeth God: and that al≈øo what≈øoeuer is giuen for their comfort, is giuen to Chri≈øt him≈øelfe, & is ≈øo accepted of him, that he will mercifully reward the ≈øame. The which Almes and deuotion of the people, the Keepers of the keyes ≈øhall yeerely, quarterly, or oftner (as need requireth) take out of the Che≈øt, and di≈øtribute the ≈øame in the pre≈øence of mo≈øt of the Pari≈øh, or ≈øixe of the chiefe of them, to bee truely and faithfully deliuered to their mo≈øt poore and needy neighbours.

div.head: LXXXV. Churches to be kept in ≈øufficient reparations.
div.p:
THe Churchwardens or que≈øtmen ≈øhall take care and prouide that the Churches bee well and ≈øufficiently repaired, and ≈øo from time to time kept and maintained, that the Windowes bee well glazed, and that the Floores be kept paued, plaine, and euen, and all things there in ≈øuch an orderly and decent ≈øort, without du≈øt, or any thing that may bee
either noi≈øome, or vn≈øeemely, as be≈øt becommeth the hou≈øe of God, and is pre≈øcribed in an Homily to that effect. The like care they ≈øhall take, that the Churchyards bee well and ≈øufficiently repaired, fenced, and maintained, with Walles, Railes, or Pales, as haue beene in each place accu≈øtomed, at their charges vnto whom by Lawe the ≈øame appertaineth: but e≈øpecially they ≈øhall ≈øee that in euery meeting of the Congregation, peace be well kept, and that all per≈øons Excommunicated, and ≈øo denounced, be kept out of the Church.

div.head: LXXXVI. Churches to be ≈øuruayed, and the decayes certified to the high Commi≈øsioners.
div.p:
EVery Deane, Deane and Chapter, Archdeacon, and others which haue authoritie to holde Eccle≈øia≈øticall Vi≈øitations by Compo≈øition, Law or Pre≈øcription, ≈øhall ≈øuruay the Churches of his or their Iuri≈ødiction, once in euery three yeeres in his owne per≈øon, or cau≈øe the ≈øame to bee done, and ≈øhall from time to time within the ≈øaid three yeeres, certifie the high Commi≈øsioners for cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øticall, euery yeere of ≈øuch defects in any
the ≈øaid Churches, as hee or they doe finde to remaine vnrepaired, and the names and ≈øurnames of the parties faultie therein. Vpon which Certificat we de≈øire that the ≈øayd high Commi≈øsioners will Ex Officio mero ≈øend for ≈øuch parties, and compel them to obey the iu≈øt and lawfull Decrees of ≈øuch Eccle≈øia≈øticall Ordinaries, making ≈øuch Certificates.

div.head: LXXXVII. A Terrier of Glebelands, and other Po≈ø≈øe≈øsions belonging to Churches.
div.p: WE ordaine that the Archbi≈øhop and all Bi≈øhops within their ≈øeuerall Dioce≈ø≈øes, ≈øhall procure (as much as in them lieth) that a true note and Terrier of all the Glebes, Lands, Meadowes, Gardens, Orchards, Hou≈øes, Stockes, Implements, Tenements, & portions of Tithes lying out of their Pari≈øhes which belong to any Par≈øonage or Vicarage, or rurall Prebend, bee taken by the view of hone≈øt men in euery Pari≈øh, by the appointment of the Bi≈øhop, whereof the Mini≈øter to bee one, and bee laid vp in the Bi≈øhops Regi≈øtrie, there to be for a perpetuall memorie thereof.

div.head: LXXXVIII. Churches not to be prophaned.
div.p: THe Churchwardens or Que≈øtmen and their A≈øsi≈øtants ≈øhall ≈øuffer no Playes, Fea≈øts, Banquets, Suppers, Church-ales, Drinkings, temporall Courts or Leetes, Lay-iuries, Mu≈øters, or any other prophane v≈øage to be kept in the Church, Chappel, or Churchyard, neither the Bels to be rong ≈øuper≈øtitiou≈øly, vpon Holydayes or Eues, abrogated by the Booke of Common prayer, nor at any other times without good cau≈øe to be allowed by the Mini≈øter of the place, and by them≈øelues.

div.head: ¬∂Churchwardens or Que≈øtmen, and Sidemen or A≈øsi≈øtants.
LXXXIX. The choi≈øe of Churchwardens and their accompt.
div.p:
AL Churchwardens or Que≈øtmen in euery Pari≈øh, ≈øhall bee cho≈øen by the ioynt con≈øent of the Mini≈øter and the Pari≈øhioners it it may be. But if they cannot agree vpon ≈øuch a
choi≈øe, then the Mini≈øter ≈øhall chu≈øe one, and the Pari≈øhioners an other, and without ≈øuch a ioynt or ≈øeuerall choi≈øe, none ≈øhall take vpon them to be Churchwardens, neither ≈øhal they continue any longer then one yere in that Office, except perhaps they be cho≈øen againe in like manner. And all Churchwardens at the end of their yeere, or within a moneth after at the mo≈øt, ≈øhall before the Mini≈øter and the Pari≈øhioners giue vp a iu≈øt accompt of ≈øuch money as they haue receiued, and al≈øo what particularly they haue be≈øtowed in reparations, and otherwi≈øe for the v≈øe of the Church. And la≈øt of all going out of their Office, they ≈øhall truely deliuer vp to the Pari≈øhioners what≈øoeuer money, or other things of right belonging to the Church or Pari≈øh, which remaineth in their hands, that it may bee deliuered ouer by them to the next Churchwardens by Bill Indented.

div.head: XC. The choy≈øe of Sidemen and their ioynt Office with Churchwardens.
div.p:
THe Churchwardens or Que≈øtmen of euery Pari≈øh, and two or three or moe
di≈øcreet per≈øons in euery Pari≈øh to bee cho≈øen for Sidemen or A≈øsi≈øtants, by the Mini≈øter and Pari≈øhioners, if they can agree, (otherwi≈øe to bee appointed by the Ordinarie of the Dioce≈ø≈øe) ≈øhall diligently ≈øee, that all the Pari≈øhioners duely re≈øort to their Church vpon all Sundayes and Holy dayes, and there continue the whole time of diuine Seruice: and none to walke or to ≈øtand idle or talking in the Church, or in the Church-yard, or Church-porch during that time. And all ≈øuch as ≈øhall bee found ≈ølacke or negligent in re≈øorting to the Church, (hauing no great or vrgent cau≈øe of ab≈øence) they ≈øhall earne≈øtly call vpon them: and after due monition (if they amend not) they ≈øhall pre≈øent them to the Ordinarie of the place. The choice of which per≈øons, viz. Church-wardens or Que≈øtmen, Sidemen or A≈øsi≈øtants, ≈øhall bee yeerely made in Ea≈øter weeke.

div.head: ¬∂Pari≈øh Clearks.
XCI. Pari≈øh Clearks to be cho≈øen by the Mini≈øter.
div.p:
NO Pari≈øh Clearke vpon any vacation ≈øhalbe cho≈øen within the Citie of London, or el≈øewhere within the Prouince of Canterbury, but by the Par≈øon or Vicar: or where there is no Par≈øon or Vicar, by the Mini≈øter of that place for the time being: Which choice ≈øhall bee ≈øignified by the ≈øaid Mini≈øter, Vicar, or Par≈øon, to the Pari≈øhioners the next Sunday following in the time of Diuine Seruice. And the ≈øaid Clearke ≈øhalbe of twenty yeeres of age at the lea≈øt, and knowen to the ≈øaide Par≈øon, Vicar or Mini≈øter to be of hone≈øt conuer≈øation, and ≈øufficient for his Reading, Writing, and al≈øo for his competent skil in Singing (if it may be.) And the ≈øaid Clearks ≈øo cho≈øen, ≈øhall haue and receiue their ancient Wages, without fraude or diminution, either at the handes of the Church-wardens at ≈øuch times as hath bene accu≈øtomed, or by their
owne collection according to the mo≈øt ancient cu≈øtome of euery Pari≈øh.

div.head: ¬∂Eccle≈øia≈øticall Courts belonging to the Archbi≈øhops Iuri≈ødiction.
XCII. None to bee Cited into diuers Courts for probate of the ≈øame Will.
div.p:
FOra≈ømuch as many heretofore haue bene by Apparitors both of inferiour Courts, and of the Courts of the Archbi≈øhops Prerogatiues much di≈øtracted, and diuer≈øly called, and ≈øummoned for probate of Willes, or to take admini≈øtrations of the goods of per≈øons dying inte≈øtate, and are thereby vexed and grieued with many cau≈øele≈ø≈øe and vnnece≈ø≈øary troubles, mole≈øtations, and expences: Wee con≈øtitute and appoint, That all Chancellors, Commi≈ø≈øaries or Officials, or any other exerci≈øing Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction what≈øoeuer, ≈øhall at the fir≈øt charge with an
othe all per≈øons called, or voluntarily appearing before them for the probate of any Will, or the Admini≈øtration of any goods, whether they know, or (moued by any ≈øpeciall inducement) doe firmely beleeue that the partie decea≈øed (who≈øe Te≈øtament or goods depend now in que≈øtion) had at the time of his or her death, any goods or good debts, in any other Dioce≈ø≈øe or Dioce≈ø≈øes, or peculiar Iuri≈ødiction within that Prouince, then in that wherein the ≈øaid party died, amounting to the value of fiue pounds. And if the ≈øaid per≈øon cited, or voluntarily appearing before him, ≈øhall vpon his oath affirme, That hee knoweth, or (as afore≈øaid) firmely beleeueth, that the ≈øaid party decea≈øed had goods or good debts in any other Dioce≈ø≈øe or Dioce≈ø≈øes, or peculiar Iuri≈ødiction within the ≈øaid Prouince, to the value afore≈øaide, and particularly ≈øpecifie and declare the ≈øame: then ≈øhall he pre≈øently di≈ømi≈ø≈øe him, not pre≈øuming to intermeddle with the probate of the ≈øaid Will, or to grant Admini≈øtration of the goods of the party ≈øo dying Inte≈øtate: neither ≈øhall hee require or exact any other charges of the ≈øaid parties more then ≈øuch onely as
are due for the Citation, and other Proce≈ø≈øe had and v≈øed again≈øt the ≈øaid parties, vpon their further contumacie: but ≈øhal openly and plainely declare and profe≈ø≈øe, that the ≈øaide cau≈øe belongeth to the Prerogatiue of the Archbi≈øhop of that Prouince, willing and admoni≈øhing the partie to prooue the ≈øaid Will, or require Admini≈øtration of the ≈øaid goods in the Court of the ≈øaid Prerogatiue, and to exhibite before him the ≈øaide Iudge the probate or admini≈øtration vnder the ≈øeale of the Prerogatiue within forty daies next following. And if any Chancellor, Commi≈ø≈øary, Official, or other exerci≈øing Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction what≈øoeuer, or any their Regi≈øter ≈øhall offend herein, let him be ip≈øo facto ≈øu≈øpended from the execution of his Office, not to be ab≈øolued or relea≈øed vntil he haue re≈øtored to the party all expences by him layed out contrary to the tenor of the premi≈ø≈øes: and euery ≈øuch probate of any Te≈øtament or admini≈øtration of goods ≈øo granted, ≈øhall be held voyd and fru≈øtrate to all effects of the Law what≈øoeuer.

Furthermore wee charge and enioyne, that the Regi≈øter of euery inferior Iudge doe without
all difficultie or delay, certifie and informe the Apparitor of the Prerogatiue Court, repairing vnto him once a moneth and no oftner, what Executors or Admini≈øtrators haue bene by his ≈øaid Iudge for the incompetencie of his owne Iuri≈ødiction, di≈ømi≈ø≈øed to the ≈øaid Prerogatiue Court within the moneth next before, vnder paine of a moneths ≈øu≈øpen≈øion from the exerci≈øe of his Office for euery default therein. Prouided, that this Canon or any thing therein contained, bee not preiudiciall to any compo≈øition betweene the Archbi≈øhop and any Bi≈øhop or other Ordinary, nor to any inferior Iudge that ≈øhall graunt any probate of Te≈øtament or admini≈øtration of goods to any party that ≈øhall voluntarily de≈øire it, both out of the ≈øaid inferior Court, and al≈øo out of the Prerogatiue. Prouided likewi≈øe, that if any man die In itinere, the goods that he hath about him at that pre≈øent, ≈øhall not cau≈øe his Te≈øtament or Admini≈øtration to be liable vnto the Prerogatiue Court.

div.head: XCIII. The Rate of Bona notabilia liable to the Prerogatiue Court.
div.p:
FVrthermore wee decree and ordaine, that no Iudge of the Archbi≈øhops Prerogatiue ≈øhall henceforward Cite, or cau≈øe to be Cited Ex officio any per≈øon what≈øoeuer to any of the afore≈øaid intents, vnle≈ø≈øe hee haue knowledge that the partie decea≈øed was at the time of his death po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of goods and chattels in ≈øome other Dioce≈ø≈øe or Dioce≈ø≈øes, or peculiar Iuri≈ødiction within that Prouince then in that wherein hee died, amounting to the value of fiue pounds at the lea≈øt, decreeing and declaring, that who ≈øo hath not goods in diuers Dioce≈ø≈øes to the ≈øaid Summe or value, ≈øhal not be accounted to haue bona notabilia. Alwayes prouided, that this clau≈øe here, and in the former Con≈øtitution mentioned, ≈øhall not preiudice tho≈øe Dioce≈ø≈øes where by compo≈øition or cu≈øtome bona notabilia are rated at a greater ≈øumme. And if any Iudge of the Prerogatiue Court, or any his Surrogate or his Regi≈øter or Apparitor, ≈øhall Cite or cau≈øe any per≈øon to be Cited into his Court contrary to the tenor of the premi≈ø≈øes, he ≈øhall re≈øtore to the party ≈øo Cited all his co≈øts and charges, and the actes and proceedings in that behalfe ≈øhall bee held
voide and fru≈øtrate. Which expences if the ≈øaid Iudge or Regi≈øter or Apparitor ≈øhal refu≈øe accordingly to pay, he ≈øhalbe ≈øu≈øpended from the exerci≈øe of his Office vntill he yeeld to the performance thereof.

div.head: XCIIII. None to be Cited into the Arches or Audience but dwellers within the Archbi≈øhops Dioce≈øse or Peculiars.
div.p:
NO Deane of the Arches nor Officiall of the Archbi≈øhops Con≈øi≈øtory, nor any Iudge of the Audience, ≈øhall henceforward in his own name or in the name of the Archbi≈øhop either ex Officio or at the in≈øtance of any party, originally Cite, Summon, or any way compell, or procure to be Cited, Summoned, or compelled, any per≈øon which dwelleth not within the particular Dioce≈ø≈øe or Peculiar of the ≈øaid Archbi≈øhop, to appeare before him or any of them for any cau≈øe or matter what≈øoeuer belonging to Eccle≈øia≈øtical cognizance, without the Licence of the Dioce≈øan fir≈øt had and obtained in that behalfe, other then in ≈øuch particular ca≈øes onely as are expre≈øly excepted and re≈øerued in and by a Statute Anno
23. H. 8. cap. 9. And if any of the ≈øaid Iudges ≈øhall, offend herein, he ≈øhall for euery ≈øuch offence be ≈øu≈øpended from the exerci≈øe of his office for the ≈øpace of three whole moneths.

div.head: XCV. The re≈øtraint of double Quarrels.
div.p:
ALbeit by former Con≈øtitutions of the Church of England, euery Bi≈øhop hath had two moneths ≈øpace to inquire and informe him≈øelfe of the ≈øufficiencie, and qualities of euery Mini≈øter, after he hath bene pre≈øented vnto him to bee in≈øtituted into any Benefice: yet for the auoiding of ≈øome inconueniences, wee doe now abridge and reduce the ≈øaid two moneths vnto eight & twenty dayes onely. In re≈øpect of which abridgement, wee doe ordaine & appoint, that no double Quarrell ≈øhal hereafter be granted out of any of the Archbi≈øhops Courts at the ≈øuite of any Mini≈øter who≈øoeuer, except hee ≈øhall fir≈øt take his per≈øonall oath, that the ≈øaid eight and twentie dayes at the lea≈øt are expired, after he fir≈øt tendered his pre≈øentation to the Bi≈øhop, and that he refu≈øed to grant him In≈øtitution thereupon: or ≈øhall enter bonds with ≈øufficient ≈øureties to
prooue the ≈øame to be true, vnder paine of ≈øu≈øpen≈øion of the Granter thereof from the execution of his Office, for halfe a yeere toties quoties to be denounced by the ≈øaid Archbi≈øhop, and Nullitie of the double Quarrell afore≈øaid, ≈øo vnduely procured, to all intents and purpo≈øes what≈øoeuer. Alwayes prouided that within the ≈øaid eight and twentie daies, the Bi≈øhop ≈øhall not in≈øtitute any other to the preiudice of the ≈øaid partie before pre≈øented, ≈øub poena nullitatis.

div.head: XCVI. Inhibitions not to be granted without the ≈øub≈øcription of an Aduocate.
div.p:
THat the Iuri≈ødictions of Bi≈øhops may be pre≈øerued (as neere as may be) entier and free from preiudice, and that for the behoofe of the Subiects of this land, better proui≈øon be made that henceforward they be not grieued with friuolous and wrongfull ≈øuits and mole≈øtations: It is ordained and prouided that no Inhibition ≈øhall bee graunted out of any Court, belonging to the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury at the in≈øtance of any partie, vnle≈ø≈øe it be ≈øub≈øcribed by an Aduocate practi≈øing in the
≈øaid Court: which the ≈øaid Aduocate ≈øhal doe freely, not taking any Fee for the ≈øame, except the partie pro≈øecuting the ≈øuit, doe voluntarily be≈øtow ≈øome gratuity vpon him for his coun≈øel and aduice in the ≈øaid cau≈øe. The like cour≈øe ≈øhall be v≈øed in graunting foorth any Inhibition at the in≈øtance of any party by the Bi≈øhop or his Chancellor again≈øt the Archdeacon, or any other per≈øon exerci≈øing Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction: and if in the Court or Con≈øi≈øtorie of any Bi≈øhop there be no aduocate at all, then ≈øhall the ≈øub≈øcription of a Proctor practi≈øing in the ≈øame Court be held ≈øufficient.

div.head: XCVII. Inhibitions not to be graunted vntill the Appeale be exhibited to the Iudge.
div.p:
IT is further ordered & decreed, that henceforward no Inhibition be granted by occa≈øion of any interlocutory decree, or in any cau≈øe of correction what≈øoeuer, except vnder the forme afore≈øaid: and moreouer that before the going out of any ≈øuch Inhibition, the Appeale it ≈øelfe, or a copie thereof (auouched by oath to be iu≈øt and true) bee exhibited to the
Iudge, or his lawfull Surrogate, whereby hee may be fully informed, both of the qualitie of the crime, and of the cau≈øe of the grieuance, before the granting foorth of the ≈øaid inhibition. And euery Appellant or his lawfull Proctor ≈øhal before the obteining of any ≈øuch Inhibition, ≈øhew and exhibite to the Iudge or his Surrogate in writing, a true copy of tho≈øe Acts wherewith hee complaineth him≈øelfe to be agrieued, and from which he appealeth, or ≈øhal take a corporall oath that hee hath performed his diligence, & true endeuor for the obteining of the ≈øame, & could not obtein it at the hands of the Regi≈øter in the Country, or his Deputy, tendring him his Fee. And if any Iudge or Regi≈øter ≈øhall either procure or permit any Inhibition to be ≈øealed, ≈øo as is ≈øaid, contrary to the forme & limitation aboue ≈øpecified, let him be ≈øu≈øpended from the execution of his office, for the ≈øpace of three moneths: If any Proctor, or other per≈øon what≈øoeuer by his appointment, ≈øhall offend in any of the premi≈ø≈øes, either by making or ≈øending out any Inhibition, contrary to the tenour of the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, let him be remoued from the exerci≈øe of his Office for
the ≈øpace of a whole yeere without hope of relea≈øe or re≈øtoring.

div.head: XCVIII. Inhibitions not to bee granted to factious Appellants, vnle≈øse they first ≈øub≈øcribe.
div.p: FOra≈ømuch as they who breake the Lawes, cannot in rea≈øon claime any benefite or protection by the ≈øame: Wee decree and appoint, that after any Iudge Eccle≈øia≈øticall hath proceeded Iudicially again≈øt ob≈øtinate and factious per≈øons, and contemners of Ceremonies, for not ob≈øeruing the Rites and Orders of the Church of England, or for contempt of Publike prayer, no Iudge ad quem, ≈øhall admit or allow any his or their Appeales, vnle≈ø≈øe he hauing fir≈øt ≈øeene the originall Appeale, the partie appellant doe fir≈øt per≈øonally promi≈øe and auow, that he wil faithfully keepe and ob≈øerue all the Rites and Ceremonies of the Church of England, as al≈øo the pre≈øcript fourme of Common prayer: and doe likewi≈øe ≈øub≈øcribe to the three Articles formerly by vs ≈øpecified and declared.

div.head: XCIX. None to marry within the degrees prohibited.
div.p: NO per≈øons ≈øhall marrie within the degrees prohibited by the Lawes of God and expre≈ø≈øed in a Table ≈øet forth by authoritie in the yeere of our Lord God 1563. and all marriages ≈øo made & contacted ≈øhall bee adiudged ince≈øtuous and vnlawfull, and con≈øequently ≈øhall be di≈ø≈øolued as voyd from the beginning, and the parties ≈øo married ≈øhall by cour≈øe of Law be ≈øeparated. And the afore≈øaid Table ≈øhall be in euery Church publikely ≈øet vp and fixed at the charge of the Pari≈øh.

div.head: C. None to marrie vnder xxj. yeeres, without their Parents con≈øent.
div.p: NO children vnder the age of one and twentie yeeres complete, ≈øhall contract them≈øelues, or marrie without the con≈øent of their Parents, or of their Guardians and Gouernours, if their Parents be decea≈øed.

div.head: CI. By whom Licences to marrie without Bannes ≈øhal be granted, and to what ≈øort of per≈øons.
div.p:
NO Facultie or Licence ≈øhalbe henceforth granted for ≈øolemnization of Matrimonie betwixt any parties, without thrice
open publication of the Bannes according to the booke of Common prayer, by any per≈øon exerci≈øing any Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction, or claiming any Priuiledges in the right of their Churches: but the ≈øame ≈øhalbe granted onely by ≈øuch as haue Epi≈øcopall authoritie, or the Commi≈ø≈øary for Faculties, Vicars generall of the Archbi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops ≈øede plena, or ≈øede vacante, the Guardian of the Spiritualties or Ordinaries exerci≈øing of right Epi≈øcopal Iuri≈ødiction in their ≈øeuerall Iuri≈ødictions re≈øpectiuely, and vnto ≈øuch per≈øons onely as bee of good ≈øtate and qualitie, and that vpon good caution and ≈øecuritie taken.

div.head: CII. Securitie to be taken at the graunting of ≈øuch Licences, and vnder what conditions.
div.p:
THe ≈øecuritie mentioned ≈øhall containe the≈øe conditions: Fir≈øt, that at the time of the granting euery ≈øuch Licence, there is not any impediment of precontract, con≈øanguinitie, affinitie, or other lawfull cau≈øe to hinder the ≈øaid marriage. Secondly, that there is not any controuer≈øie or ≈øuit depending in any Court before any Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iudge touching
any contract or marriage of either of the ≈øaid parties with any other. Thirdly, that they haue obtained thereunto the expre≈ø≈øe con≈øent of their parents (if they be liuing) or otherwi≈øe of their Guardians or Gouernours. La≈øtly, that they ≈øhall celebrate the ≈øaid Matrimonie publikely in the Pari≈øh Church or Chappell where one of them dwelleth, and in no other place, and that betweene the houres of eight and twelue in the forenoone.

div.head: CIII. Oathes to be taken for the conditions.
div.p:
FOr the auoiding of all fraud and collu≈øion in the obtaining of ≈øuch Licences & Di≈øpen≈øations: We further con≈øtitute and appoint, That before any Licence for the Celebration of Matrimonie, without publication of Bannes be had or granted, it ≈øhall appeare to the Iudge by the oathes of two ≈øufficient witne≈ø≈øes, one of them to be knowen either to the Iudge him≈øelfe, or to ≈øome other per≈øon of good reputation then pre≈øent, and knowen likewi≈øe to the ≈øaid Iudge, that the expre≈ø≈øe con≈øent of the Parents, or Parent if one bee dead, or Gardians, or Gardian of the parties is
thereunto had and obtained. And furthermore that one of the parties per≈øonally ≈øweare, that he beleeueth there is no let or impediment of precontract, kindred, or alliance, or of any other lawfull cau≈øe what≈øoeuer, nor any ≈øuite commenced in any Eccle≈øia≈øticall Court, to bar or hinder the proceeding of the ≈øaid Matrimonie, according to the tenour of the fore≈øaid Licence.

div.head: CIIII. An exception of tho≈øe that are in Widowhood.
div.p:
IF both the parties which are to marry being in Widowhood, do ≈øeeke a Facultie for the forbearing of Bannes, then the clau≈øes before mentioned, requiring the Parents con≈øents, may be omitted: but the Pari≈øhes where they dwell both ≈øhall be expre≈ø≈øed in the Licence, as al≈øo the Pari≈øh named where the Marriage ≈øhall be celebrated. And if any Commi≈ø≈øary for Faculties, Vicars generall, or other the ≈øaid Ordinaries ≈øhal offend in the premi≈ø≈øes, or any part thereof, he ≈øhall for euery time ≈øo offending, be ≈øu≈øpended from the execution of his Office for the ≈øpace of ≈øixe moneths: and euery ≈øuch Licence or di≈øpen≈øation ≈øhall be held
voyd to al effects and purpo≈øes, as if there had neuer bene any ≈øuch granted: and the parties marrying by vertue thereof, ≈øhall bee ≈øubiect to the puni≈øhments which are appointed for Clande≈øtine Marriages.

div.head: CV. No Sentence for Diuorce to bee giuen vpon the ≈øole confe≈øsion of the parties.
div.p:
FOra≈ømuch as Matrimoniall cau≈øes haue bene alwayes reckoned and reputed among≈øt the weightie≈øt, and therefore require the greater caution when they come to be handled and debated in Iudgement, e≈øpecially in cau≈øes wherein Matrimonie hauing bene in the Church duely ≈øolemnized, is required vpon any ≈øugge≈øtion or pretext what≈øoeuer to bee di≈ø≈øolued or annulled: Wee doe ≈øtraightly charge and inioyne, that in all proceedings to Diuorce and Nullities of Matrimonie, good circum≈øpection and aduice bee v≈øed, and that the trueth may (as farre as is po≈øsible) bee ≈øifted out by the depo≈øition of witne≈ø≈øes , and oth ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lawfull proofes and euictions, and that credit be not giuen to the ≈øole confe≈øsion of the parties them≈øelues, how≈øoeuer
taken vpon oath, either within or without the Court.

div.head: CVI. No Sentence for Diuorce to be giuen but in open Court.
div.p: NO Sentence ≈øhall be giuen either for ≈øeparation √† thoro & men≈øa, or for annulling of pretended Matrimonie, but in open Court, and in the ≈øeat of Iu≈øtice, and that with the knowledge and con≈øent either of the Archbi≈øhop within his Prouince, or of the Bi≈øhop within his Dioce≈ø≈øe, or of the Deane of the Arches, the Iudge of the Audience of Canterbury, or of the Vicars general, or other principall Officials, or ≈øede vacante, of the Guardians of the Spiritualties, or other Ordinaries to whom of right it apperteineth, in their ≈øeuerall Iuri≈ødictions and Courts, and concerning them onely that are then dwelling vnder their Iuri≈ødictions.

div.head: CVII. In all Sentences for Diuorce, bond to be taken for not marrying, during each others life.
div.p:
IN all Sentences pronounced onely for Diuorce and Separation, √† thoro & men≈øa,
there ≈øhall bee a caution and re≈øtraint in≈øerted in the Act of the ≈øaid Sentence, That the parties ≈øo ≈øeparated, ≈øhal liue cha≈øtly & continently: neither ≈øhall they, during each others life, contract Matrimonie with any other per≈øon. And for the better ob≈øeruing of this la≈øt clau≈øe, the ≈øaid Sentence of Diuorce ≈øhall not be pronounced, vntill the partie or parties requiring the ≈øame, haue giuen good and ≈øufficient caution & ≈øecuritie into the Court, that they will not any way breake or trangre≈ø≈øe the ≈øaid re≈øtraint or prohibition.

div.head: CVIII. The penaltie for Iudges offending in the premi≈øses.
div.p: ANd if any Iudge giuing Sentence of Diuorce or Separation, ≈øhall not fully keepe and ob≈øerue the premi≈ø≈øes, he ≈øhall be by the Archibi≈øhop of the Prouince, or by the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, ≈øu≈øpended from the exerci≈øe of his Office for the ≈øpace of a whole yere, and the Sentence of Separation ≈øo giuen contrary to the forme afore≈øaid, ≈øhal be held voyd to all intents and purpo≈øes of the Law, as if it had not at all bene giuen or pronounced.

div.head: ¬∂Eccle≈øia≈øtical Courts belonging to the Iuri≈ødiction of Bi≈øhops and Archdeacons, and the proceedings in them.
CIX. Notorious Crimes and Scandals to be certified into Eccle≈øiasticall Courts by pre≈øentment.
div.p: IF any offend their brethren, either by Adulterie, whoredome, Ince≈øt, or Drunkenne≈ø≈øe, or by Swearing, Ribaldrie, V≈øurie, or any other vncleanne≈ø≈øe and wickedne≈ø≈øe of life, the Church-wardens or Que≈øtmen and Sidemen in their next Pre≈øentments to their Ordinaries, ≈øhall faithfully pre≈øent all and euery of the ≈øaid offenders, to the intent that they and euery of them may bee puni≈øhed by the ≈øeueritie of the Lawes, according to their de≈øerts, and ≈øuch notorious offendours ≈øhall not be admitted to the holy Communion till they be reformed.

div.head: CX. Schi≈ømaticks to be pre≈øented.
div.p: IF the Churchwardens or Que≈øtmen or A≈ø≈øi≈øtants, doe or ≈øhall know any man within their Pari≈øh or el≈øewhere, that is a hinderer of the word of God to bee read or ≈øincerely Preached, or of the execution of the≈øe our Con≈øtitutions, or a fautor of any v≈øurped or forreine power by the Lawes of this Realme iu≈øtly reiected and taken away, or a defender of Popi≈øh and erroneous doctrine: they ≈øhall detect and pre≈øent the ≈øame to the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe or Ordinarie of the place, to bee cen≈øured & puni≈øhed, according to ≈øuch Eccle≈øia≈øtical Lawes as are pre≈øcribed in that behalfe.

div.head: CXI. Di≈øturbers of diuine Seruice to be pre≈øented.
div.p: IN all Vi≈øitations of Bi≈øhops and Archdeacons, the Churchwardens or Que≈øtmen and Sidemen ≈øhall truely and per≈øonally pre≈øent the names of all tho≈øe, which behaue them≈øelues rudely or di≈øorderly in the Church, or which by vntimely ringing of Bels, by walking, talking, or other noy≈øe ≈øhall hinder the Mini≈øter or Preacher.

div.head: CXII. Not Communicants at Easter to be pre≈øented.
div.p: THe Mini≈øter, Church-wardens, Que≈øtmen & A≈øsi≈øtants of euery Pari≈øh church and Chappell, ≈øhall yeerely within fortie daies after Ea≈øter exhibite to the Bi≈øhop or his Chancellor, the names and ≈øurnames of all the Pari≈øhioners, a≈øwell men as women, which being of the age of ≈øixteene yeeres, receiued not the Communion at Ea≈øter before.

div.head: CXIII. Mini≈øters may pre≈øent.
div.p:
BEcau≈øe it often commeth to pa≈ø≈øe that the Churchwardens, Sidemen, Que≈øtmen, and ≈øuch other per≈øons of the Laytie as are to take care for the ≈øuppre≈øsing of ≈øinne and wickedne≈ø≈øe in their ≈øeuerall Pari≈øhes, as much as in them lieth, by admonition, reprehen≈øion & denunciation to their Ordinaries, doe forbeare to di≈øcharge their duties therein, either through feare of their Superiours, or through negligence, more then were fit, the licentiou≈øne≈ø≈øe of the≈øe times con≈øidered: Wee ordaine, That hereafter euery Par≈øon and Vicar, or in the lawfull ab≈øence of any Par≈øon or
Vicar, then their Curates and Sub≈øtitutes may ioyne in euery pre≈øentment with the ≈øayde Churchwardens, Sidemen, and the re≈øt aboue mentioned at the times hereafter limited, if they the ≈øaid Churchwardens and the re≈øt will pre≈øent ≈øuch enormities as are apparant in the Pari≈øh: or if they wil not, then euery ≈øuch Par≈øon and Vicar, or in their ab≈øence as afore≈øaid their Curates may them≈øelues pre≈øent to their Ordinaries at ≈øuch times, and when el≈øe they thinke it meete, all ≈øuch crimes as they haue in charge, otherwi≈øe, as by them (being the per≈øons that ≈øhould haue the chiefe care for the ≈øuppre≈øsing of ≈øinne and impiety in their Pari≈øhes) ≈øhall be thought to require due reformation. Prouided alwayes, that if any man confe≈ø≈øe his ≈øecret and hidden ≈øins to the Mini≈øter for the vnburthening of his con≈øcience, and to receiue ≈øpiritual con≈øolation and ea≈øe of minde from him, We do not any way binde the ≈øaid Mini≈øter by this our Con≈øtitution, but do ≈øtraightly charge and admoni≈øh him, that he do not at any time reueale & make knowen to any per≈øon what≈øoeuer, any crime or offence ≈øo committed to his tru≈øt and ≈øecrecie
(except they bee ≈øuch crimes as by the Lawes of this Realme, his owne life may be called into que≈øtion for concealing the ≈øame) vnder paine of irregularitie.

div.head: CXIIII. Mini≈øters ≈øhall pre≈øent Recu≈øants.
div.p:
EVery Par≈øon, Vicar, or Curate, ≈øhall carefully informe them≈øelues euery yere hereafter, how many Popi≈øh Recu≈øants, men, women & children aboue the age of thirteene yeeres, and how many being popi≈øhly giuen (who though they come to the Church, yet doe refu≈øe to receiue the Communion) are inhabitants, or make their abode either as Soiourners or common Gue≈øts in any of their ≈øeuerall Pari≈øhes, and ≈øhall ≈øet downe their true names in writing (if they can learne them) or otherwi≈øe ≈øuch names as for the time they cary, di≈øtingui≈øhing the ab≈øolute Recu≈øants from halfe Recu≈øants: and the ≈øame ≈øo farre as they know or beleeue ≈øo di≈øtingui≈øhed & ≈øet downe vnder their hands, ≈øhall truely pre≈øent to their Ordinaries before the Fea≈øt of the Natiuitie next en≈øuing, vnder paine of ≈øu≈øpen≈øion to bee inflicted vpon them by their ≈øaid Ordinaries,
and ≈øo euery yeere hereafter vpon the like paine, before the Fea≈øt of S. Iohn Bapti≈øt. Al≈øo we ordaine, that all ≈øuch Ordinaries, Chancellours, Commi≈ø≈øaries, Archdeacons, Officials, and all other Eccle≈øia≈øticall Officers, to whom the ≈øaid pre≈øentments ≈øhall be exhibited, ≈øhall likewi≈øe within one moneth after the receit of the ≈øame, vnder paine of ≈øu≈øpen≈øion by the Bi≈øhop from the execution of their Offices for the ≈øpace of halfe a yere (as often as they ≈øhall offend therein) deliuer them or cau≈øe to be deliuered to the Bi≈øhop re≈øpectiuely: who ≈øhall al≈øo exhibite them to the Archbi≈øhop within ≈øixe weekes, and the Archbi≈øhop to his Maie≈øtie within other ≈øixe weekes after he hath receiued the ≈øaid pre≈øentments.

div.head: CXV. Mini≈øters and Churchwardens not to bee ≈øued for Pre≈øenting.
div.p:
WHereas for the reformation of criminous per≈øons and di≈øorders in euery Pari≈øh, the Churchwardens, Que≈øtmen, Sidemen, and ≈øuch other Church Officers are ≈øworne, and the Mini≈øter charged to pre≈øent as well the crimes and di≈øorders committed
by the ≈øaid criminous per≈øons, as al≈øo the common fame which is ≈øpread abroad of them, whereby they are often maligned and ≈øometimes troubled by the ≈øaid Delinquents or their friends: We doe admoni≈øh and exhort all Iudges both Eccle≈øia≈øticall and Temporall, as they regard and reuerence the fearefull iudgement ≈øeate of the highe≈øt Iudge, that they admit not in any of their Courts, any complaint, plea, ≈øuit, or ≈øuits, again≈øt any ≈øuch Churchwarden, Que≈øtmen, Sidemen, or other Church officers for making any ≈øuch pre≈øentments, nor again≈øt any Mini≈øter for any pre≈øentment that hee ≈øhall make: all the ≈øaid pre≈øentments tending to the re≈øtraint of ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe impietie, and con≈øidering that the rules both of Charitie and Gouernment doe pre≈øume that they did nothing therein of malice, but for the di≈øcharge of their con≈øciences.

div.head: CXVI. Churchwardens not bound to Pre≈øent oftner then twice a yeere.
div.p:
NO Churchwardens, Que≈øtmen, or Sidemen of any Pari≈øh, ≈øhall bee inforced to exhibite their pre≈øentments to any hauing
Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction aboue once in euery yeere, where it hath bene no oftner v≈øed, nor aboue twi≈øe in any Dioce≈ø≈øe what≈øoeuer, except it be at the Bi≈øhops Vi≈øitation. For the which pre≈øentments of euery Pari≈øh Church or Chappell, the Regi≈øter of any Court where they are to be exhibited, ≈øhall not receiue in one yeere aboue foure pence, vnder paine for euery offence therein, of ≈øu≈øpen≈øion from the execution of his Office for the ≈øpace of a moneth toties quoties. Prouided alwayes that as good occa≈øion ≈øhall require, it ≈øhall be lawfull for euery Mini≈øter, Churchwardens, and Sidemen, to pre≈øent offenders as oft as they ≈øhall thinke meete. And likewi≈øe for any godly di≈øpo≈øed per≈øon, or for any Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iudge, vpon knowledge or notice giuen vnto him or them of any enormious crime within his Iuri≈ødiction, to moue the Mini≈øter, Churchwardens, or Sidemen, as they tender the glory of God and reformation of ≈øinne, to pre≈øent the ≈øame, if they ≈øhall finde ≈øufficient cau≈øe to induce them thereunto, that it may bee in due time puni≈øhed and reformed. Prouided that for the≈øe voluntarie pre≈øentments, there be no
Fee required or taken of them, vnder the paine afore≈øaid.

div.head: CXVII. Churchwardens not to be troubled for not pre≈øenting oftner then twi≈øe a yeere.
div.p:
NO Churchwardens, Que≈øtmen, or Sidemen ≈øhall be called or cited, but onely at the ≈øaid time or times before limited, to appeare before any Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iudge who≈øoeuer, for refu≈øing at other times to pre≈øent any faults committed in their Pari≈øhes, and puni≈øhable by Eccle≈øia≈øticall lawes. Neither ≈øhall they nor any of them after their pre≈øentments exhibited at any of tho≈øe times be any further troubled for the ≈øame, except vpon manif ‚Ä¢ ≈øt and euident proofe it may appeare that they did then willingly and wittingly omit to pre≈øent ≈øome ≈øuch publike crime or crimes as they knew to be committed, or could not be ignorant that there was then a publike fame of them, or vnle≈ø≈øe there be very iu≈øt cau≈øe to call them for the explanation of their former pre≈øentments. In which ca≈øe of wilfull omi≈øsion, their Ordinaries ≈øhall proceed again≈øt them in ≈øuch ≈øort as in cau≈øes of wilfull periury in a
Court Eccle≈øia≈øticall it is alreadie by Law prouided.

div.head: CXVIII. The old Churchwardens to make their Pre≈øentments before the new be ≈øworne.
div.p:
THe office of al Churchwardens and Sidemen ≈øhall bee reputed euer hereafter to continue vntill the new Churchwardens that ≈øhall ≈øucceed them, be ≈øworne, which ≈øhal be the fir≈øt weeke after Ea≈øter, or ≈øome weeke following, according to the direction of the Ordinary. Which time ≈øo appointed, ≈øhall alwayes be one of the two times in euery yeere, when the Mini≈øter and Churchwardens, and Sidemen of euery Pari≈øh ≈øhall exhibite to their ≈øeuerall Ordinaries, the pre≈øentments of ≈øuch enormities as haue happened in their Pari≈øhes ≈øince their la≈øt pre≈øentments. And this duetie they ≈øhall performe before the newly cho≈øen Churchwardens and Sidemen be ≈øworne, and ≈øhall not be ≈øuffered to pa≈ø≈øe ouer the ≈øaid pre≈øentments to tho≈øe that are newly come into office, and are by intendment ignorant of ≈øuch crimes, vnder paine of tho≈øe cen≈øures which are appointed for the reformation of ≈øuch dalliers
and di≈øpen≈øers with their owne con≈øciences and oathes.

div.head: CXIX. Conuenient time to be a≈øsigned for framing Pre≈øentments.
div.p:
FOr the auoyding of ≈øuch inconueniences as heretofore haue happened by the ha≈øty making of Billes of Pre≈øentments, vpon the dayes of the Vi≈øitation and Synods: it is ordered, That alwayes hereafter euery Chancellor, Archdeacon, Commi≈ø≈øary, and Officiall, and euery other per≈øon hauing Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction at the ordinary time when the Churchwardens are ≈øworne: and the Archbi≈øhop and Bi≈øhops when he or they doe ≈øummon their Vi≈øitation, ≈øhall deliuer, or cau≈øe to be deliuered to the Churchwardens, Que≈øtmen, and Sidemen of euery Pari≈øh, or to ≈øome of them, ≈øuch Bookes of Articles as they or any of them ≈øhall require for the yeere following the ≈øaid Churchwardens, Que≈øtmen, and Sidemen to ground their Pre≈øentments vpon at ≈øuch times as they are to exhibite them. In which Booke ≈øhall be contained the forme of the oath which mu≈øt be taken immediatly before
euery ≈øuch Pre≈øentment: to the intent that hauing before hand time ≈øufficient, not onely to peru≈øe and con≈øider what their ≈øayd oath ≈øhalbe, but the Articles al≈øo whereupon they are to ground their Pre≈øentments, they may frame them at home both adui≈øedly and truely to the di≈øcharge of their owne con≈øcienences, after they are ≈øworne, as becommeth hone≈øt and godly men.

div.head: CXX. None to bee Cited into Eccle≈øia≈øticall Courts by Proce≈øse of Quorum nomina.
div.p: NO Bi≈øhop, Chancellor, Archdeacon, Officiall or other Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iudge, ≈øhall ≈øuffer any generall Proce≈ø≈øes of Quorum nomina, to bee ≈øent out of his Court: except the names of all ≈øuch as thereby are to be cited, ≈øhalbe fir≈øt expre≈øly entred by the hand of the Regi≈øter, or his Deputie, vnder the ≈øaid Proce≈ø≈øes, and the ≈øayd Proce≈ø≈øes and names be fir≈øt ≈øub≈øcribed by the Iudge, or his Deputie, and his Seale thereto affixed.

div.head: CXXI. None to bee Cited into ≈øeuerall Courts for one crime.
div.p:
IN places where the Bi≈øhop and Archdeacon, doe by pre≈øcription or compo≈øition vi≈øite at ≈øeuerall times in one and the ≈øame yeere, lea≈øt for one and the ≈øelfe ≈øame fault any of his Maie≈øties Subiects ≈øhould bee challenged & mole≈øted in diuers Eccle≈øia≈øtical Courts We order and appoint, That euery Archdeacon, or his Officiall, within one moneth after the Vi≈øitation ended that yeere, and the Pre≈øentments receiued, ≈øhall certifie vnder his Hand and Seale, to the Bi≈øhop or his Chancellor, the names and Crimes of all ≈øuch as are detected and pre≈øented in his ≈øaid Vi≈øitation, to the end the Chancellor ≈øhall thencefoorth forbeare to conuent any per≈øon for any Crime or cau≈øe ≈øo detected or pre≈øented to the Archdeacon. And the Chancellor within the like time after the Bi≈øhops Vi≈øitation ended, and Pre≈øentments receiued, ≈øhall vnder his Hand and Seale ≈øignifie to the Archdeacon or his Official, the names and Crimes of all ≈øuch per≈øons which ≈øhall be detected or pre≈øented vnto him in that Vi≈øitation, to the ≈øame intent as is afore≈øaid. And if the≈øe Officers ≈øhall not certifie each other as is here pre≈øcribed, or after
≈øuch certificate ≈øhall intermeddle with the crimes or per≈øons detected and pre≈øented in each others Vi≈øitation: then euery of them ≈øo offending ≈øhall be ≈øu≈øpended from all exerci≈øe of his Iuri≈ødiction, by the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, vntill he ≈øhall repay the co≈øts and expences which the parties grieued haue bene at by that vexation.

div.head: CXXII. No ≈øentence of depriuation or depo≈øition to bee pronounced again≈øt a Mini≈øter, but by the Bi≈øhop.
div.p:
WHen any Mini≈øter is complained of in any Eccle≈øia≈øticall Court belonging to any Bi≈øhop of this Prouince for any Crime, the Chancellor, Commi≈ø≈øarie, Officiall or any other hauing Eccle≈øia≈øtical Iuri≈ødiction to whom it ≈øhall appertaine, ≈øhal expedite the cau≈øe by Proce≈ø≈øes and other proceedings again≈øt him: and vpon contumacie for not appearing, ≈øhal fir≈øt ≈øu≈øpend him, & afterward his contumacie continuing, Excommunicate him. But if he appeare and ≈øubmit him≈øelfe to the cour≈øe of Law, then the matter being ready for Sentence, and the merits of his
offence exacting by Law, either depriuation from his liuing, or depo≈øition from the Mini≈øtery, no ≈øuch ≈øentence ≈øhall bee pronounced by any per≈øon what≈øoeuer, but only by the Bi≈øhop, with the a≈øsi≈øtance of his Chancellor, the Deane, (if they may conueniently bee had) and ≈øome of the Prebendaries, if the Court be kept neere the Cathedrall Church, or of the Archdeacon if he may bee had conueniently, and two other at the lea≈øt graue Mini≈øters and Preachers to be called by the Bi≈øhop, when the Court is kept in other places.

div.head: CXXIII. No Act to be ≈øped but in open Court.
div.p: NO Chancellor, Commi≈ø≈øary, Archdeacon, Officiall, or any other per≈øon v≈øing Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction who≈øoeuer, ≈øhall ≈øpeed any iudiciall Act, either of contentious or voluntary Iuri≈ødiction, except he haue the ordinary Regi≈øter of that Court, or his lawfull Deputy: or if hee or they will not, or cannot be pre≈øent, then ≈øuch per≈øons as by law are allowed in that behalfe to write or ≈øpeede the ≈øame, vnder paine of ≈øu≈øpen≈øion ip≈øo facto.

div.head: CXXIIII. No Court to haue more then one Seale.
div.p: NO Chancellor, Commi≈ø≈øarie, Archdeacon, Official, or any other exerci≈øing Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction, ≈øhal without the Bi≈øhops con≈øent haue any mo Seales then one for the Sealing of all matters incident to his Office. Which Seale ≈øhall alwayes be kept either by him≈øelfe, or by his lawfull Sub≈øtitute exerci≈øing Iuri≈ødiction for him, and remaining within the Iuri≈ødiction of the ≈øaid Iudge, or in the Citie or principall Towne of the Countie. This Seale ≈øhall containe the title of that Iuri≈ødiction which euery of the ≈øaid Iudges or their Deputies doe execute.

div.head: CXXV. Conuenient places to bee cho≈øen for the keeping of Courts.
div.p:
ALl Chancellors, Commi≈ø≈øaries, Archdeacons, Officials, and all other exerci≈øing Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction, ≈øhall appoint ≈øuch meete places for the keeping of their Courts by the a≈øsignement or approbation of the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe, as ≈øhall bee conuenient for entertainement of tho≈øe that are to
make their appearance there, and mo≈øt indifferent for their trauell. And likewi≈øe they ≈øhall keepe and end their Courts in ≈øuch conuenient time, as euery man may returne homewards in as due ≈øea≈øon as may be.

div.head: CXXVI. Peculiar and inferiour Courts to exhibite the originall copies of Willes into the Bi≈øhops Regi≈øtrie.
div.p:
WHereas Deanes, Archdeacons, Prebendaries, Par≈øons, Vicars, & others exerci≈øing Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction, claime libertie to proue the la≈øt Willes & Te≈øtaments of per≈øons decea≈øed within their ≈øeuerall Iuri≈ødictions, hauing no knowen nor certaine Regi≈øters, nor publike place to keepe their Records in, by rea≈øon whereof many Willes, Rights, and Legacies vpon the death or change of ≈øuch per≈øons and their priuate Notaries, mi≈øcarry and cannot bee found, to the great preiudice of his Maie≈øties Subiects: We therefore order and inioyne, that all ≈øuch Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øours & Exerci≈øers of peculiar Iuri≈ødiction, ≈øhall once in euery yeere exhibite into the publike Regi≈øtrie of the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe,
or of the Deane & Chapter vnder who≈øe Iuri≈ødiction the ≈øaid Peculiars are, euery originall Te≈øtament of euery per≈øon in that time decea≈øed and by them proued in their ≈øeuerall peculiar Iuri≈ødictions, or a true Copie of euery ≈øuch Te≈øtament examined, ≈øub≈øcribed, and ≈øealed by the peculiar Iudge and his Notarie. Otherwi≈øe if any of them faile ≈øo to doe, the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe or Deane and Chapter vnto whom the ≈øaid Iuri≈ødictions doe re≈øpectiuely belong, ≈øhall ≈øu≈øpend the ≈øaid parties and euery of them from the exerci≈øe of all ≈øuch peculiar Iuri≈ødiction, vntill they haue performed this our Con≈øtituion.

div.head: ¬∂Iudges Eccle≈øia≈øticall and their Surrogates.
CXXVII. The qualitie and oath of Iudges.
div.p:
NO man ≈øhall hereafter be admitted a Chancellor, Commi≈ø≈øary, or Official, to exerci≈øe any Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction, except hee be of the full age of ≈øixe and twentie yeeres at
the lea≈øt, and one that is learned in the Ciuill and Eccle≈øia≈øticall Lawes, and is at the lea≈øt a Ma≈øter of Arts, or Bachelor of Law, and is rea≈øonably well practi≈øed in the cour≈øe thereof, as likewi≈øe well affected, and zealou≈øly bent to Religion, touching who≈øe life and maners no euill example is had, & except before he enter into or execute any ≈øuch Office, hee ≈øhall take the oath of the Kings Supremacie in the pre≈øence of the Bi≈øhop, or in the open Court, and ≈øhall ≈øub≈øcribe to the Articles of Religion agreed vpon in the Conuocation in the yeere one thou≈øand fiue hundred ≈øixtie and two, and ≈øhall al≈øo ≈øweare that he will to the vttermo≈øt of his vnder≈øtanding, deale vprightly and iu≈øtly in his Office, without re≈øpect or fauour of reward: the ≈øaid oathes and ≈øub≈øcription to be recorded by a Regi≈øter then pre≈øent. And likewi≈øe all Chancellors, Commi≈ø≈øaries, Officials, Regi≈øters, and all other that do now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe or execute any places of Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction, or Seruice, ≈øhall before Chri≈øtmas next in the pre≈øence of the Archbi≈øhop or Bi≈øhop, or in open Court, vnder whom or where they exerci≈øe their Offices, take the ≈øame
oathes and ≈øub≈øcribe as before is ≈øaid: or vpon refu≈øall ≈øo to doe, ≈øhall be ≈øu≈øpended from the execution of their Offices, vntill they ≈øhal take the ≈øaid oathes, and ≈øub≈øcribe as afore≈øaid.

div.head: CXXVIII. The qualitie of Surrogats.
div.p:
NO Chancellor, Commi≈ø≈øary, Archdeacon, Officiall, or any other per≈øon v≈øing Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction, ≈øhall at any time ≈øub≈øtitute in their ab≈øence any to keepe any Court for them, except hee bee either a graue Mini≈øter and a Graduate, or a licen≈øed publike Preacher, and a Beneficed man neere the place where the Courts are kept, or a Bachelor of Law, or a Ma≈øter of Arts at lea≈øt, who hath ≈øome skill in the Ciuill and Eccle≈øia≈øticall Law, and is a fauourer of true Religion, and a man of mode≈øt and hone≈øt conuer≈øation, vnder paine of Su≈øpen≈øion for euery time that they offend therein from the execution of their Offices for the ≈øpace of three moneths Toties quoties. And hee likewi≈øe that is Deputed, being not qualified as is before expre≈ø≈øed, and yet ≈øhall pre≈øume to be a Sub≈øtitute
to any Iudge, and ≈øhall keepe any Court as is afore≈øaid, ≈øhal vndergoe the ≈øame cen≈øure in maner and forme as is before expre≈ø≈øed.

div.head: ‚ùßProctors.
CXXIX. Proctors not to retaine Cau≈øes, without the lawfull a≈øsignement of the parties.
div.p:
NOne ≈øhall Procure in any cau≈øe what≈øoeuer, vnle≈ø≈øe he be thereunto con≈øtituted and appointed by the partie him≈øelfe, either before the Iudge, and by Act in Court, or vnle≈ø≈øe in the beginning of the Suit, hee be by a true and ≈øufficient Proxie thereunto warranted and enabled. Wee call that Proxie ≈øufficient, which is ≈øtrengthened and confirmed by ≈øome authenticall Seale, the parties approbation, or at lea≈øt his ratification therewithall concurring. All which Proxies ≈øhall be forthwith by the ≈øayd Proctors exhibited into the Court, and be ≈øafely kept and pre≈øerued by the Regi≈øter in the publike Regi≈øtrie of the ≈øaide Court. And if any Regi≈øter or Proctor ≈øhall
offend herein, he ≈øhall bee ≈øecluded from the exerci≈øe of his Office for the ≈øpace of two moneths without hope of relea≈øe or re≈øtoring.

div.head: CXXX. Proctors not to retaine Cau≈øes without the coun≈øell of an Aduocate.
div.p:
FOr le≈ø≈øening and abridging the multitude of Suits and contentions, as al≈øo for preuenting the complaints of Suiters in Courts Eccle≈øia≈øticall, who many times are ouerthrowen by the ouer≈øight and negligence, or by the ignorance and in≈øufficiencie of Proctors, and likewi≈øe for the furtherance and increa≈øe of learning, and the aduancement of Ciuil and Canon Law, following the laudable cu≈øtomes heretofore ob≈øerued in the Courts pertaining to the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, Wee will and ordaine, that no Proctor exerci≈øing in any of them ≈øhall intertaine any Cau≈øe what≈øoeuer, and keepe and retaine the ≈øame for two Court dayes, without the Coun≈øell and adui≈øe of an Aduocate, vnder paine of a yeeres ≈øu≈øpen≈øion from his practi≈øe: neither ≈øhall the Iudge haue power to relea≈øe or mitigate
the ≈øaid penaltie, without expre≈ø≈øe Mandate and Authoritie from the Archbi≈øhop afore≈øaid.

div.head: CXXXI. Proctors not to conclude in any Cau≈øe, without the knowledge of an Aduocate.
div.p: NO Iudge in any of the ≈øaid Courts of the Archbi≈øhop, ≈øhall admit any Libell, or any other matter without the aduice of an Aduocate admitted to practi≈øe in the ≈øame Court, or without his ≈øub≈øcription: neither ≈øhall any Proctor conclude any cau≈øe depending, without the knowledge of the Aduocate retained and feed in the cau≈øe: which if any Proctor ≈øhall doe, or procure to bee done, or ≈øhall by any colour what≈øoeuer defraud the Aduocate of his duetie or Fee, or ≈øhall be negligent in repairing to the Aduocate, and requiring his aduice what cour≈øe is to bee taken in the cau≈øe, he ≈øhalbe ≈øu≈øpended from all practi≈øe for the ≈øpace of ≈øixe moneths, without hope of being thereunto re≈øtored, before the ≈øaid terme be fully complete.

div.head: CXXXII. Proctors prohibited the oath In animam Domini ≈øui.
div.p:
FOra≈ømuch as in the probate of Te≈øtaments and Suits for admini≈øtration of the goods of per≈øons dying Inte≈øtate, the oath v≈øually taken by Proctors of Courts In animam con≈øtituentis, is found to be inconuenient: Wee doe therefore decree & ordaine, That euery Executor or Suitor for admini≈øtration, ≈øhall per≈øonally repaire to the Iudge in that behalfe, or his Surrogate, and in his owne per≈øon (and not by Proctor) take the oath accu≈øtomed in the≈øe ca≈øes. But if by rea≈øon of ≈øickne≈ø≈øe or age, or any other iu≈øt let or impediment, he be not able to make his per≈øonall appearance before the Iudge, it ≈øhall bee lawfull for the Iudge (there being faith fir≈øt made by a credible per≈øon, of the trueth of his ≈øaid hinderance or impediment) to grant a Commi≈øsion to ≈øome graue Eccle≈øia≈øticall per≈øon abiding neere the partie afore≈øaid, whereby hee ≈øhall giue power and authoritie to the ≈øaid Eccle≈øia≈øticall per≈øon in his ≈øtead, to mini≈øter the accu≈øtomed oath
aboue mentioned, to the Executor or Suitor for ≈øuch admini≈øtration, requiring his ≈øaide Sub≈øtitute, that by a faithfull and tru≈øtie me≈ø≈øenger hee certifie the ≈øayd Iudge truely and faithfully what he hath done therein. La≈øtly, we ordaine and appoint, That no Iudge or Regi≈øter, ≈øhall in any wi≈øe receiue for the Writing, Drawing, or Sealing of any ≈øuch Commi≈øsion, aboue the ≈øumme of ≈øixe ≈øhillings and eight pence: whereof one moitie to bee for the Iudge, and the other for the Regi≈øter of the ≈øaid Court.

div.head: CXXXIII. Proctors not to be clamorous in Court.
div.p:
FOra≈ømuch as it is found by experience, that the lowd and confu≈øed cries and clamours of Proctors in the Courts of the Archbi≈øhop, are not onely trouble≈øome and offen≈øiue to the Iudges & Aduocates, but al≈øo giue occa≈øion to the ≈øtanders by, of contempt and calumnie toward the Court it ≈øelfe: that more re≈øpect may be had to the dignity of the Iudge, then heretofore, and that cau≈øes may more ea≈øily and commodiou≈øly bee handled
and di≈øpatched, We charge and enioyne, That all Proctors in the ≈øaid Courts do e≈øpecially intend, that the Acts be faithfully entred and ≈øet downe by the Regi≈øter, according to the aduice and direction of the Aduocate, that the ≈øaid Proctors refraine loude ≈øpeech, and brabling, and behaue them≈øelues quietly and mode≈øtly, and that when either the Iudges or Aduocates, or any of them, ≈øhal happen to ≈øpeake, they pre≈øently be ≈øilent vpon paine of ≈øilencing for two whole Termes then immediatly following euery ≈øuch offence of theirs. And if any of them ≈øhall the ≈øecond time offend herein, & after due monition ≈øhall not reforme him≈øelfe: let him be for euer remoued from his practi≈øe.

div.head: ‚ùß Regi≈øters.
CXXXIIII. Abu≈øes to be reformed in Regi≈øters.
div.p:
IF any Regi≈øter, or his Deputie, or Sub≈øtitute what≈øoeuer, ≈øhall receiue any Certificate without the knowledge and con≈øent of the Iudge of the Court, or willingly omit to
cau≈øe any per≈øons cited to appeare vpon any Court day to be called, or vnduely put off, and deferre the Examination of witne≈ø≈øes to be examined by a day ≈øet & a≈øsigned by the Iudge, or doe not obey and ob≈øerue the iudiciall and lawfull monition of the ≈øaid Iudge, or omit to write, or cau≈øe to be written ≈øuch Citations and Decrees, as are to be put in execution and ≈øet foorth before the next Court day, or ≈øhall not cau≈øe all Te≈øtaments exhibited into his Office to bee Regi≈øtred within a conuenient time, or ≈øhall ≈øet downe or enact as decreed by the Iudge any thing fal≈øe, or conceited by him≈øelfe, and not ≈øo ordered or decreed by the Iudge, or in the tran≈ømi≈øsion of Proce≈ø≈øes to the Iudge Ad quem, ≈øhall adde, or in≈øert any fal≈øehood or vntrueth, or omit any thing therein, either by cunning, or by gro≈ø≈øe negligence, or in cau≈øes of In≈øtance, or promoted of Office, ≈øhall receiue any reward in fauour of either partie, or be of coun≈øel directly or indirectly with either of the parties in Suite, or in the execution of their Office, ≈øhall doe ought el≈øe maliciou≈øly, or fraudulently, whereby the ≈øaid Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iudge or his proceedings may be ≈ølandred
or defamed: We wil and ordaine that the ≈øaid Regi≈øter of his Deputie or Sub≈øtitute, offending in all, or any of the premi≈ø≈øes, ≈øhall by the Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈ø≈øe be ≈øu≈øpended from the exerci≈øe of his Office, for the ≈øpace of one, two or three moneths, or more, according to the qualitie of his offence, and that the ≈øayde Bi≈øhop ≈øhal a≈øsigne ≈øome other publike Notarie to execute and di≈øcharge all things pertaining to his Office, during the time of his ≈øayd Su≈øpen≈øion.

div.head: CXXXV. A certaine rate of Fees due to all Eccle≈øia≈øticall Officers.
div.p:
NO Bi≈øhop, Suffragan, Chancellor, Commi≈ø≈øarie, Archdeacon, Officiall, nor any other exerci≈øing Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iuri≈ødiction what≈øoeuer, nor any Regi≈øter of any Eccle≈øia≈øticall Courts, nor any Mini≈øter belonging to any of the ≈øaid Officers or Courts, ≈øhal hereafter for any cau≈øe incident to their ≈øeueral Offices, take or receiue any other or greater Fees, then ≈øuch as were certified to the mo≈øt Reuerend Father in God Iohn late Archbi≈øhop of Canterburie, in the yeere of our Lord God,
one thou≈øand fiue hundred ninetie and ≈øeuen, and were by him ratified and approued, vnder paine that euery ≈øuch Iudge, Officer, or Mini≈øter offending herein ≈øhall be ≈øu≈øpended from the exerci≈øe of their ≈øeuerall Offices, for the ≈øpace of ≈øixe moneths for euery ≈øuch offence. Alwayes prouided that if any que≈øtion ≈øhall ari≈øe concerning the certaintie of the ≈øaid Fees or any of them: then tho≈øe Fees ≈øhall be held for lawfull, which the Archbi≈øhop of Canterburie for the time being ≈øhall vnder his hand approoue, except the Statutes of this Realme before made, doe in any particular ca≈øe expre≈ø≈øe ≈øome other Fees to be due. Prouided furthermore, that no Fee or money ≈øhall bee receiued either by the Archbi≈øhop or any Bi≈øhop, or Suffragan, either directly or indirectly, for admitting of any into ≈øacred Orders, nor that any other per≈øon or per≈øons vnder the ≈øaid Archbi≈øhop, Bi≈øhop, or Suffragan, ≈øhall for Parchment, Writing, Waxe, Sealing, or any other re≈øpect thereunto appertaining, take aboue ten ≈øhillings, vnder ≈øuch paines as are already by Law pre≈øcribed.

div.head: CXXXVI. A Table of the Rates of Fees to bee ≈øet vp in Courts and Registries.
div.p:
WE do likewi≈øe con≈øtitute and appoint, that the Regi≈øters belonging to euery ≈øuch Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iudge, ≈øhall place two Tables, containing the ≈øeuerall Rates, and Summes of all the ≈øaid Fees: one in the v≈øuall place or Con≈øi≈øtorie where the Court is kept, and the other in his Regi≈øtrie, & both of them in ≈øuch ≈øort, as euery man whom it concerneth may without difficultie come to the view and peru≈øall thereof, and take a Copie of them: the ≈øame Tables to be ≈øo ≈øet vp before the Fea≈øt of the Natiuitie next en≈øuing. And if any Regi≈øter ≈øhall faile to place the ≈øaid Tables according to the tenor hereof, he ≈øhal be ≈øu≈øpended from the execution of his Office, vntil he cau≈øe the ≈øame to be accordingly done: and the ≈øaid Tables being once ≈øet vp, if hee ≈øhall at any time remooue or ≈øuffer the ≈øame to be remooued, hidden, or any way hindered from ≈øight, contrary to the true meaning of this Con≈øtitution, he ≈øhall for euery ≈øuch offence be ≈øu≈øpended
from the exerci≈øe of his Office for the ≈øpace of ≈øixe moneths.

div.head: CXXXVII. The whole Fees for ≈øhewing letters of Orders, and other Licen≈øes due but once in euery Bi≈øhops time.
div.p:
FOra≈ømuch as a chiefe and principall cau≈øe and v≈øe of Vi≈øitation is, that the Bi≈øhop, Archdeacon, or other a≈øsigned to Vi≈øite, may get ≈øome good knowledge of the State, Sufficiencie, and Abilitie of the Cleargie, and other per≈øons whom they are to Vi≈øite: Wee thinke it conuenient that euery Par≈øon, Vicar, Curate, Schoolema≈øter, or other per≈øon licenced who≈øoeuer, doe at the Bi≈øhops fir≈øt Vi≈øitation, or at the next Vi≈øitation after his Admi≈øsion, ≈øhew and exhibite vnto him his Letters of Orders, In≈øtitution, and Induction, and all other his Di≈øpen≈øations, Licences, or Faculties what≈øoeuer, to bee by the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop either allowed or (if there be iu≈øt cau≈øe) di≈øallowed and reiected: and being by him approued, to be as the Cu≈øtome is, ≈øigned by the Regi≈øter, and that the whole Fees accu≈øtomed to
bee payed in the Vi≈øitations in re≈øpect of the premi≈ø≈øes, bee payed onely once in the whole time of euery Bi≈øhop, and afterwards, but halfe of the ≈øaide accu≈øtomed Fees, in euery other Vi≈øitation during the ≈øaid Bi≈øhops continuance.

div.head: ¬∂ Apparitors.
CXXXVIII. The number of Apparitors restrained.
div.p:
FOra≈ømuch as wee are de≈øirous to redre≈ø≈øe ≈øuch abu≈øes and aggrieuances as are ≈øaide to grow by Sumners or Apparitors: Wee thinke it meete that the multitude of Apparitors be (as much as is po≈øsible) abridged or re≈øtrained. Wherefore we decree and ordaine, that no Bi≈øhop or Archdeacon, or their Vicars or Officials, or other inferior Ordinaries, ≈øhall depute or haue more Apparitors to ≈øerue in their Iuri≈ødictions re≈øpectiuely, then either they or their predece≈ø≈øors were accu≈øtomed to haue thirtie yeeres before the publi≈øhing of
the≈øe our pre≈øent Con≈øtitutions. All which Apparitors ≈øhall by them≈øelues faithfully execute their Offices, neither ≈øhall they by any colour or pretence what≈øoeuer cau≈øe or ≈øuffer their Mandats to be executed by any Me≈ø≈øengers or Sub≈øtitutes, vnle≈ø≈øe it bee vpon ≈øome good cau≈øe to be fir≈øt knowen and approued by the Ordinarie of the place. Moreouer, they ≈øhall not take vpon them the office of Promoters or Informers for the Court, neither ≈øhall they exact more or greater Fees then are in the≈øe our Con≈øtitutions formerly pre≈øcribed. And if either the number of the Apparitors deputed ≈øhall exceed the fore≈øaid limitation, or any of the ≈øaide Apparitors ≈øhall offend in any of the premi≈ø≈øes, the per≈øons deputing them, if they be Bi≈øhops, ≈øhall vpon admonition of their ≈øuperiour di≈øcharge the per≈øons exceeding the number ≈øo limitted: if inferiour Ordinaries, they ≈øhall be ≈øu≈øpended from the execution of their Office vntill they haue di≈ømi≈ø≈øed the Apparitors by them ≈øo deputed, & the parties them≈øelues ≈øo deputed ≈øhall for euer be remooued from the Office of Apparitors: and if being ≈øo remoued, they de≈øi≈øt not
from the exerci≈øe of their ≈øaid Offices, let them be puni≈øhed by Eccle≈øia≈øticall cen≈øures as per≈øons contumacious. Prouided, that if vpon experience the number of the ≈øaid Apparitors be too great in any Dioce≈ø≈øe, in the iudgement of the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury for the time being, they ≈øhall by him be ≈øo abridged, as hee ≈øhall thinke meete and conuenient.

div.head: ¬∂ Authoritie of Synodes.
CXXXIX. A Nationall Synode the Church repre≈øentatiue.
div.p:
WHo≈øoeuer ≈øhall hereafter affirme, that the Sacred Synode of this Nation in the Name of CHRIST, and by the Kings Authoritie a≈ø≈øembled, is not the true Church
of ENGLAND by repre≈øentation, let him be Excommunicated, and not re≈øtored, vntill hee repent and publikely reuoke that his wicked error.

div.head: CXL. Synodes conclude as well the ab≈øent as the pre≈øent.
div.p: WHo≈øoeuer ≈øhall affirme, that no maner of per≈øon either of the Clergie or Laitie, not being them≈øelues particularly a≈ø≈øembled in the ≈øaid ≈øacred Synode, are to be ≈øubiect to the Decrees thereof in cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øticall (made and ratified by the Kings Maie≈øties ≈øupreme Authoritie) as not hauing giuen their voices vnto them: let him bee Excommunicated, and not re≈øtored vntill hee repent and publikely reuoke that his wicked error.

div.head: CXLI. Deprauers of the Synode, cen≈øured.
div.p:
WHo≈øoeuer ≈øhall hereafter affirme, That the ≈øacred Synode a≈ø≈øembled as afore≈øaid, was a company of ≈øuch per≈øons as did con≈øpire together again≈øt godly and Religious profe≈ø≈øors of the Go≈øpel: and
that therefore both they and their proceedings, in making of Canons and Con≈øtitutions in cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øticall by the Kings authoritie as afore≈øaid, ought to be de≈øpi≈øed and contemned, the ≈øame being ratified, confirmed, and enioyned by the ≈øaid Regall Power, Supremacie, and Authoritie: let them be Excommunicated and not re≈øtored, vntill they repent and publikely reuoke that wicked error.

WE of our princely inclination, and Royall care for the maintenance of the pre≈øent E≈øtate and Gouernement of the Church of ENGLAND, by the Lawes of this our Realme now ≈øetled and e≈øtabli≈øhed, hauing diligently, with great contentment and comfort, read and con≈øidered of all the≈øe their ≈øayd Canons, Orders, Ordinances, and Con≈øtitutions agreed vpon, as is before expre≈ø≈øed; and finding the ≈øame ≈øuch, as Wee are per≈øwaded will bee very profitable, not onely to our Clergie, but to the whole Church of this our kingdome, and to all the true members of it, (if they be well ob≈øerued) Haue therefore for ∆≤s, our
Heires, and lawfull Succe≈ø≈øours, of our e≈øpeciall Grace, certaine Knowledge, and meere Motion giuen, and by the≈øe pre≈øents doe giue our Royall a≈ø≈øent, according to the forme of the ≈øayd Statute or Acte of Parliament afore≈øayd, to all and euery of the ≈øaid Canons, Orders, Ordinances, and Con≈øtitutions, and to all and euery thing in them contained, as they are before written.

And furthermore, Wee doe not onely by our ≈øayd Prerogatiue Royall, and ≈øupreme Authoritie in cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øticall, ratifie, confirme, and e≈øtabli≈øh by the≈øe our Letters Patents, the ≈øayd Canons, Orders, Ordinances, and Con≈øtitutions, and all and euery thing in them contayned,
